BY YOUR COMMAND;

        There's a misrepresentation here regarding drugs and chemistry in
general, MDMA is being used as a scape goat for the flaws of modern
medicine, science, and pharmacology.

        Most, if not all substances produced, and or modified by man for
internal ingestion into the human body have a statistic death rate
associated with them.

        We are very naive to believe that in an infinitely diverse society
made up of human beings,  for the most part who are totally unlike one
another that anything we take, for the most part will have the same effect
across the board. People, this belief and the belief that medicine and
science have all the answers is poppy cock. No so called science is exact,
not one, sorry. The fact is people are going to die, from safe substances
from all substances, it is our basic nature to be different, and this
includes different reactions to different substances ranging from the
extreme to the common to none.

        I strongly implore you to pick up any addition of the PDR, the
Physicians Desk Reference and look at the drugs page by page, and I know
that you will find at least 75% of the substances listed there have either
killer, harmed, or least made people sick from either the substance itself
or with combinations of food as simple and as harmless as everyday American
cheese eg MAO Inhibitors commonly used in the treatment of depression.
Tylenol found in every household in American according to the very
conservative poison control people taken in doses of 40 grams or more are
far more deadly the a single dose of MDMA for most people. Not to mention
the horrible, & prolonged way you die from a Tylenol overdose, provided you
don't receive the antidote in 16 - 24 hours.

        Some medications deemed therapeutic have very serious and harmful
long term side affects so severe and potentially harmful that the people
taking these drugs have to be routinely monitored by medical staff eg
Teg-ra-tol commonly used in the treatment of seizure disorders.

        Most of the new medications like Prozac, sold as the miracle drug of
the 90's internal actions on the body and causes of the side effects are
unknown to humankind at present. This is stated in the PRD under Prozac,
Actions category.

        I totally agree with the fact that if you don't know who's making
the substance, you have no assurance of it's ingredients or the level of
quality control. 

        But please don't attempt to blame a substance that until 1985 was
deemed by the very analy conservative FDA as safe and therapeutic. Blame the
people or either cut, and/or compromise, the original recipe for reasons of
lack of safe approved production chemicals/equipment and or greed.

        Blame our government for it's futile oppression for substances that
are clearly wanted and desired BY THE PEOPLE, who are supposedly living in
the free world. Yet alcohol, and tobacco are still the number one killers
and are still legal.

        I dream of a day when science is exact, and no more people have to
die because we are so clueless in our understanding of ourselves. I dream of
the day when our defense budget looks more like our budget for medical
research, health & welfare of the people of the world. I dream of a day when
we live in a society where people believe in themselves rather than the need
for some external substance or a belief that a non-existent God will save them.

        I respect life among all things, and anytime someone dies an
original masterpiece, a priceless work of art is lost to us all, for we are
then less than what we were. 

        But what is life without freedom of thought, expression, dreams,
trust, action(provided it doesn't directly harm another) ...etc. Many
religious people would stay that this is the bibles definition of
hell.............

        So I ask you, will totally abolishing this substance from the planet
even mildly improve the condition of our planet, and or the human condition.
Please if someone out there can give me hard clear, beyond a shadow of a
doubt & my own experience that this will happen, then you will have my total
support in this effort.

        But in the defense of MDMA, it HELPED me end a 32 year prison of
sexual & emotional isolation, a living hell. Where the wonder drugs failed,
where the therapeutic minds of America couldn't help, I am free as a result
of this drug, and myself. Where one finds life & freedom, another may find
death, this is the human condition and for right now and it is not ours to
change.............

Sincerely
Brian Darknes^2

PS        I strongly encourage private, informed, intelligent, non-character
assasinating debate on this topic, and please sight your sources when your
stating facts......

At 01:21 PM 2/18/96 PST, Peter Jones wrote:
>On the Matter of MDMA Use
>=========================
>
>Bruce Eisner wrote today (Feb. 18, 1996):
>
>   "I can safely report that, to paraphrase Mark Twain, the 
>    "reports of ecstasy deaths has been greatly exaggerated."
>    .... The [Journal of Clinical Psychology] study [by C.M.Milroy
>    et al., 1996, Vol. 49, pp. 149-153] was obviously designed 
>    to produce fear in the public about a drug which has been 
>    shown to be remarkably safe when used in moderate doses at 
>    infrequent intervals."
>
>My son Morgan's death on April 30 last year from a moderate dose 
>of Ecstasy was not greatly exaggerated.
>
>Nicholas Saunders (author of "E is for Ecstasy") wrote on Sept. 26,
>in reply to my Sept. 25 posting about Morgan's death:
>
>   "However, I do stand by my conclusion about the relative 
>    safety of MDMA, ... taken sensibly and in moderation by 
>    healthy people, the risks of taking MDMA are no more than 
>    many other accepted forms of recreation, and are probably 
>    less than alcohol use....
>
>   "It may be cold hearted, but statistical risk is more 
>    relevant to sensible decision making than closeness to a 
>    personal tragedy."
>
>I wanted to reply to Saunders (and now also to Eisner) in a way
>that was informed and not biased because of my "closeness to a
>personal tragedy."
>
>For that reason, I asked David Smith, Founder and President of 
>the Haight Ashbury Free Clinics in San Francisco, and Rick Seymour,
>Information and Education Director of the Clinics, to draft a reply
>for me.  They very kindly agreed to do so.  I am not an expert on
>MDMA use, but I concur with them.
>
>Their statement follows.
>
>My best wishes to all of you.
>
>Peter Jones
>peter@island.com
>February 18, 1996
>
>                  ******************************
>
>                    ON THE MATTER OF MDMA USE
>        David E. Smith, M.D. and Richard B. Seymour, M.A.
>
>Peter Jones, the father of Morgan Jones, who died after ingesting
>methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), has asked us to draft a
>statement for the Internet regarding the risks involved in using
>MDMA.  We have collectively had some experience in researching
>and writing about clinical aspects of MDMA use.  Writings include a
>booked titled MDMA written by Seymour in 1986, several articles co-
>authored in the following years, and the co-chairing of a two-day
>national conference, "MDMA: A Multidisciplinary Conference," in
>1986.  Most recently, we co-authored a booklet, "The Psychedelic
>Resurgence: Treatment, Support, and Recovery Options," published by
>Hazelden.  Our findings are based on clinical observations at the
>Haight Ashbury Free Clinics and discussions with colleagues in
>addiction medicine throughout the United States and overseas.  Our
>opinions are our own, and do not represent Haight Ashbury Free
>Clinics or any other treatment center or organization.
>
>First of all, the greatest risk from taking any illegal drug is 
>that the user has no guarantee that the drug's content is what it 
>is said to be.  There is no Illicit Food and Drug Administration out 
>there protecting the user from potentially toxic substances, either 
>used as filler or as a replacement for the active ingredients the 
>drug is supposed to contain.  MDMA is no exception, and its users 
>are not immune from the greed, ignorance, carelessness of 
>unscrupulous cookers and dealers.  It has been argued that if MDMA 
>were legal, its quality could be controlled, but the reality is 
>that MDMA use and manufacture is illegal now, and most likely will 
>remain illegal for the foreseeable future.
>
>Early researchers on the potential for therapeutic use noted a 
>variety of individuals for whom taking MDMA, even at therapeutic 
>levels, is particularly risky -- physicians would say "contra-
>indicated."  These include: individuals with histories of 
>hypertension, heart disease, hyperthyroidism, diabetes mellitus, 
>hypoglycemia, seizure disorder or glaucoma.  The list also includes 
>women who are pregnant or may be pregnant, and individuals with a 
>history of socially or vocationally disabling psychological 
>conditions.  We have added from experience, anyone with a history 
>of alcohol or other drug abuse and addiction.
>
>While these contra-indications may seem clear, it must be
>remembered that most users of MDMA are young people with no
>history of these medical problems.  No history does not mean that
>these conditions don't exist.  Individuals, tragically including 
>Morgan Jones, may not know that they have a heart problem or 
>hypertension that could be triggered into a potentially fatal attack 
>by MDMA's sympathomimetic effects.  These effects, shared with such 
>stimulants as methamphetamine and cocaine, include the shrinking of 
>blood vessels (vasoconstriction) and can elevate blood pressure to
>dangerous levels for those who are at risk.  The number of 
>individuals who are at such risk and do now know it may be
>statistically small, but who wants to be a statistic?  There may be
>more chambers in the gun, but does anyone really want to pull a
>chemical trigger when the result may well be death or permanent
>disability?  We have found that some individuals, after ingesting
>MDMA, have a prolonged posthallucinogen perceptual disorder
>(PHPD) with significant neuropsychological impairment.  It has been
>suggested that the disorder is caused by MDMA induced impairment
>of the brain's serotonergic system.
>
>Individuals with a history of alcohol and other drug abuse are
>particularly at risk.  In a review of Nicholas Saunders book, 
>"E is for Ecstasy," in the "Journal of Psychoactive Drugs,"
>Volume 26(3), 1994, Richard Seymour had the following to say:
>
>"Saunders has not obscured the downside of MDMA, but one thing
>workers in the drug treatment and recovery field are apt to find
>alarming is his lack of understanding regarding the nature of
>addiction, and the message that this may communicate to individuals
>who are at risk for addictive disease.  According to Saunders, 
>"A drug is considered addictive if physical withdrawal symptoms 
>occur when a regular user stops taking it.  MDMA is not addictive 
>by this definition..."  Such a misunderstanding of addiction was 
>one of the factors that led to widespread cocaine use in the United 
>States in the general belief that because cocaine did not produce 
>the same withdrawal found with heroin and barbiturates, it was not 
>an addictive drug.  Addiction is now generally thought to be a
>progressive disease, characterized by compulsion, loss of control, 
>and continued use of a substance in spite of adverse consequences, 
>and by that definition, MDMA can be addictive.
>
>"Another point of alarm is the concept that MDMA can be used by
>individuals to self-treat their addiction to other drugs, such as 
>heroin or alcohol.  While some psychoactive drugs are used 
>therapeutically in drug detoxification, such as the use of 
>phenobarbital taper to reduce the danger of life-threatening 
>seizures during alcohol and sedative withdrawal, the self-treatment 
>of addiction with other drugs is what the recovering community calls, 
>"changing seats on the Titanic."  Switching from the use of one 
>psychoactive drug to another does nothing to alleviate addiction, 
>and in fact may make matters worse by increasing the scope of the 
>addiction to include the new drug and reinforcing the addict's 
>rationale for denial."
>
>While there are obviously dangers and concerns, there are also 
>some major public misconceptions about MDMA.  MDMA has often been 
>confused in the media with the heroin-like designer drugs, such as
>fentanyl analogs, that have been responsible for opioid overdoes,
>and with an illicit demerol analog that contained an impurity that
>caused a Parkinson's disease-like paralysis in its users.  One of the
>most persistent misconceptions, and one we hear often at the Haight
>Ashbury Free Clinics, is that MDMA somehow "drains spinal fluid."
>
>While we are both against the legalization of any further
>psychoactive drugs at this time, we do feel that legitimate clinical
>research on such substances as MDMA should be encouraged.  In the
>past, we have gone on record advocating the adoption of a treatment
>research schedule that would allow this to take place outside the
>sanctions for illicit manufacture and sale to the general public.
>Without adequate research in controlled settings, much concerning
>MDMA and other outlawed substances remains a question mark,
>creating a public health danger and making it difficult to assess 
>the full spectrum of risks involved in their use.
>
>Sincerely,
>David E. Smith, M.D.
>Richard B. Seymour, M.A.
>January 18, 1996
>
>
>                  ******************************
>
>P.S. by Peter Jones:
>
>If you are in the Bay Area, you may want to communicate
>with the Haight Ashbury Free Clinics for information
>about drugs, or for help with a problem.  Their address:
>
>The Haight Ashbury Free Clinics, Inc.  
>409 Clayton Street
>San Francisco, CA 94117
>415-487-3688
>FAX: 415-621-7354
>
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 18 23:04:36 1996

In-Reply-To: Bruce Ehrlich - Mindmedia <bruce@mindmedia.com>
        "Bruce Eisner on Ecstasy Damage Reports" (Feb 18,  9:26am)
References: <9602181728.AA04994@mail.ico.net>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)

Beg pardon, but we have had at least one death in the Bay Area in the last
year which was very likely related to MDMA use, according to the medical
report.  I agree the number of deaths and illnesses from MDMA is relatively
small, but the risk is real.  The problem is that it is so hard to know who
is at risk and should avoid it.  I am allergic to bee stings, for example,
and nearly died as a result of a dozen or so wasp stings when I was a kid.
I went into anaphylactic shock and had to be taken to the hospital, looking
like a red and white checkerboard, where they pumped me full of antihistamine
and adrenalin (a wonderful boost, I might add, but not something I'd want
to take externally ever again).  This has more or less cured me of wanting
to go for lots of hikes or wherever our flying-stinging friends are.  Of
course, it's impossible to totally avoid bees and wasps, but at least I can
minimize my risk.

With unknown chemicals from an unregulated market, it is more difficult to
deal with these risks.

I agree that the health risks of MDMA are fairly minor, but they do exist
and I think it is dangerous to say, as Bruce Eisner/Ehrlich did, that
"there is no evidence that it caused" the reported deaths in the UK or
others that have occurred in conjunction with MDMA.  Unless the medical
reports say so specifically, I think we have to go with the probability
that it was involved.  

I know a thing or two about risk analysis, and I would definitely put MDMA
use in the relatively mild category.  It's less dangerous, statistically,
than playing soccer, as the quote goes.  But given the proclivity ofthe
media to repeat the mindless scare stories of the control freaks in our
society, it's very important to be candid about the risks of all the
substances we have floating around in our society.  

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 18 23:13:50 1996

Well, just to be fair, I think Neils is going too far as well.  The numbers
for the consumption of MDMA are fairly well established, especially in the
UK where this has been the subject of considerable academic study.  
The risks quoted may be off by as much as an order of magnitude either way,
but that's not very much in the grand scheme of things.

What that gets to, and what i didn't clearly say in my last post, is that
the integrity of what we say about MDMA usage or, in general, the quality
of our "scene," can be compromised if we dodge the facts and circumstances
about MDMA.  The problem with MDMA and many other substances -- both 
non-legal *and* legal, I might add -- is that toxicity is not always
obvious, and it varies considerably by individual.  For my friend who has
acute legume sensitivity and could actually die if she eats too many peanuts,
it is a constant annoyance to have to avoid certain foods and always ask how
restaurants cook things, but at least she knows the score as far as that
class of foods go.  Myself, I love peanuts and gobble 'em frequently.  
But in both cases we know our toxicity levels.  This is not the case for
substances like MDMA and many others -- again, let me hasten to add, many
legal ones -- which our bodies are not used to encountering in external
form and for which little cultural wisdom really exists.  I mean, we know
to avoid eating raw potatoes, right?  

So what we're really talking about here is developing the understructure of
cultural wisdom about substances like MDMA so that people don't just go
blithely necking their pills and tabs without really knowing what the
dangers are and being well prepared to deal with it.

I know, I know, this is a tall order, but that's the way it is for the human
race.  We are constantly inventing new ways to get ourselves into and out
of trouble!

phred

Before turning the floor over to my esteemed colleague Rick Doblin at MAPS,
I would like to make the following comments concerning Peter Jones's post. 

While I sincerely sorry when anyone dies of drug use of any kind, as well as
deaths by many other ways that rob a person of their youth, I must make
these observations:

What drugs laws do is
1) Suppress the truth about what drugs do and what they don't do
2) Insure that peopled will take drugs without adequate knowledge and,
3) Insure that representation and contaminated drugs are consumed by youth
unconvinced by so called experts like Seymour and Smith.

With drugs laws, it would be more likely that Morgan's death may never have
occurred. What we need is wisdom and understanding to replace "Just Say No"
and Draconian drug laws, the current policy.

The greatest misunderstanding are 1) about the differences between drugs
(MDMA and LSD are not addictive in most people for example and are far safer
than alcohol and amphetamine which are addictive. And 2)confusion between
intelligent use and abuse. When these boundaries are obscured by
misinformation, the stage is set for much tragedy which has played itself in
the world during the year of the New Prohibition.  

Many of the warning given by Smith and Seymour are also given in my book.
Their list is a bit longer but I believe Rick Doblin, in the following
forward post discusses this quite well. However my book is not used as a
textbook in classes in intelligent drug use in high schools and adult
schools by most teachers. If it were, MDMA would be a much safer drug
because my book recommends that people be taught more intelligent drug use
in schools and in special centers, and that this training be funded by
replacing the current tough laws, which insure impure drugs will be consumed
by uninformed youth.

It is also true that some people have idiosyncratic reactions to many drugs.
For example, hundreds died because of adverse effects to asprrin, based on
DAWN report statistics of emergency rooms. Each of the parents or family of
those who die could lead a crusade against drug stores, but I don't think
that this would result in the popular analgesic being taken off the shelves
in drug stores.

I urge everyone has posted to read my book, Ecstasy: The MDMA Story (Ronin
Publishing Berkeley, 1989, 1994). Hundreds have people have told me that
this book has changed their lives for the better. I believe that the
ignorance must be replaced by knowledge, and that so-called experts like
Seymour and Smith, who take their money from the Government's NIDA, try a
different strategy...and they won't have so many young people strung out on
methamphetamine and heroin because they can't get clean MDMA or even MDMA at
all. And believe me, despite the urgings of these so-called experts, youth
will continue to experiment. Other cultures employ wise teachers and shamen
to train their youth in ritual, intelligent and moderate use of
mind-changing compounds. Why don't we make the world safer for them?

Bruce Eisner

Rick Doblin's comments follow


Bruce,

Here are some comments. You can post it if you like. I'm rushing to pack and
get ready to leave for Germany in a few hours.

Seymour and Smith deserve credit for coming out strongly in favor of MDMA
research. Their cautions regarding the risks of non-medical use are useful
reminders that all drugs carry some level of risk.  I evaluate the risks of
MDMA somewhat differently than Seymour and Smith.  Here are my comments on
their main concerns:

They state that early researchers felt that MDMA was contraindicated in
"individuals with histories of 
hypertension, heart disease, hyperthyroidism, diabetes mellitus,
hypoglycemia, seizure disorder or glaucoma.  The list also includes women who
are pregnant or may be pregnant, and individuals with a history of socially
or vocationally disabling psychological conditions.  We have added from
experience, anyone with a history of alcohol or other drug abuse and
addiction."


The list was originally prepared to be extremely cautious. Experience has
demonstrated that MDMA does not seem to pose a special risk to  people with
diabetes mellitus, hypoglycemia, or glaucoma.  MDMA can catalyze a seizure
but this is very rare and people with seizure disorder have taken MDMA with
no problems. MDMA raises blood pressure but it seems to be a serious risk
only in people with substantially compromised hearts. I don't know what to
say about hyperthyroidism. 

Many pregnant women have taken MDMA with no problem to their fetus. I know of
no case in the scientific literature which links MDMA to a specific birth
defect. Animal data does not suggest that MDMA causes birth defects.
Nevertheless, the use of any drug by a pregnant woman should be carefully
evaluated. 

To suggest that MDMA is contraindicated in people with alcoholism or
substance abuse disorders ignores numerous accounts of people using MDMA to
help themselves or others resolve problems of addiction to cocaine and other
drugs.  MDMA should be used cautiously by people with substance abuse
problems but the risks cannot be demonstrated to outweigh the potential
benefits (nor can the potential benefits be demonstrated to outweigh the
risks). 

MDMA itself has a low potential of addiction. Instead of "rearranging chairs
on the Titanic", the use of MDMA can help move someone from the Titanic to a
lifeboat. The seas are still rough but one's chances of survival can be
improved. This alternative outcome should not be written off as impossible.
 The key factors are preparation and follow-up support.

As to people with a history of socially or vocationally disabling
psychological conditions, what matters is the context within which MDMA is
taken. MDMA-assisted therapy can be very helful to people with a  history of
socially or vocationally disabling psychological conditions.

The comparison of taking MDMA to playing Russian roulette, "There may be more
chambers in the gun, but does anyone really want to pull a chemical trigger
when the result may well be death or permanent disability?" is excessive and
may cause Seymour and Smith's cautions to be dismissed as exaggerated
fearmongering. 

Over 120 high school students  have died in the past ten years as a result of
competitive sports injuries.  Since about 6 million kids participate every
year, the death rate is roughly 1 in 500,000. Calculating the death rate for
MDMA is more difficult. However, it is probably that not much different.  Is
playing sports in  high school like Russian roulette? No, but there are
risks.  

I concur with Seymour and Smith's endorsement of MDMA research.  We all need
more definite information so that people can more accurately decide for
themselves what level of risk is acceptible.

Rick Doblin, MAPS
February 18,1996

At 01:21 PM 2/18/96 PST, you wrote:
>On the Matter of MDMA Use
>=========================
>
>Bruce Eisner wrote today (Feb. 18, 1996):
>
>   "I can safely report that, to paraphrase Mark Twain, the 
>    "reports of ecstasy deaths has been greatly exaggerated."
>    .... The [Journal of Clinical Psychology] study [by C.M.Milroy
>    et al., 1996, Vol. 49, pp. 149-153] was obviously designed 
>    to produce fear in the public about a drug which has been 
>    shown to be remarkably safe when used in moderate doses at 
>    infrequent intervals."
>
>My son Morgan's death on April 30 last year from a moderate dose 
>of Ecstasy was not greatly exaggerated.
>
>Nicholas Saunders (author of "E is for Ecstasy") wrote on Sept. 26,
>in reply to my Sept. 25 posting about Morgan's death:
>
>   "However, I do stand by my conclusion about the relative 
>    safety of MDMA, ... taken sensibly and in moderation by 
>    healthy people, the risks of taking MDMA are no more than 
>    many other accepted forms of recreation, and are probably 
>    less than alcohol use....
>
>   "It may be cold hearted, but statistical risk is more 
>    relevant to sensible decision making than closeness to a 
>    personal tragedy."
>
>I wanted to reply to Saunders (and now also to Eisner) in a way
>that was informed and not biased because of my "closeness to a
>personal tragedy."
>
>For that reason, I asked David Smith, Founder and President of 
>the Haight Ashbury Free Clinics in San Francisco, and Rick Seymour,
>Information and Education Director of the Clinics, to draft a reply
>for me.  They very kindly agreed to do so.  I am not an expert on
>MDMA use, but I concur with them.
>
>Their statement follows.
>
>My best wishes to all of you.
>
>Peter Jones
>peter@island.com
>February 18, 1996
>
>                  ******************************
>
>                    ON THE MATTER OF MDMA USE
>        David E. Smith, M.D. and Richard B. Seymour, M.A.
>
>Peter Jones, the father of Morgan Jones, who died after ingesting
>methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA), has asked us to draft a
>statement for the Internet regarding the risks involved in using
>MDMA.  We have collectively had some experience in researching
>and writing about clinical aspects of MDMA use.  Writings include a
>booked titled MDMA written by Seymour in 1986, several articles co-
>authored in the following years, and the co-chairing of a two-day
>national conference, "MDMA: A Multidisciplinary Conference," in
>1986.  Most recently, we co-authored a booklet, "The Psychedelic
>Resurgence: Treatment, Support, and Recovery Options," published by
>Hazelden.  Our findings are based on clinical observations at the
>Haight Ashbury Free Clinics and discussions with colleagues in
>addiction medicine throughout the United States and overseas.  Our
>opinions are our own, and do not represent Haight Ashbury Free
>Clinics or any other treatment center or organization.
>
>First of all, the greatest risk from taking any illegal drug is 
>that the user has no guarantee that the drug's content is what it 
>is said to be.  There is no Illicit Food and Drug Administration out 
>there protecting the user from potentially toxic substances, either 
>used as filler or as a replacement for the active ingredients the 
>drug is supposed to contain.  MDMA is no exception, and its users 
>are not immune from the greed, ignorance, carelessness of 
>unscrupulous cookers and dealers.  It has been argued that if MDMA 
>were legal, its quality could be controlled, but the reality is 
>that MDMA use and manufacture is illegal now, and most likely will 
>remain illegal for the foreseeable future.
>
>Early researchers on the potential for therapeutic use noted a 
>variety of individuals for whom taking MDMA, even at therapeutic 
>levels, is particularly risky -- physicians would say "contra-
>indicated."  These include: individuals with histories of 
>hypertension, heart disease, hyperthyroidism, diabetes mellitus, 
>hypoglycemia, seizure disorder or glaucoma.  The list also includes 
>women who are pregnant or may be pregnant, and individuals with a 
>history of socially or vocationally disabling psychological 
>conditions.  We have added from experience, anyone with a history 
>of alcohol or other drug abuse and addiction.
>
>While these contra-indications may seem clear, it must be
>remembered that most users of MDMA are young people with no
>history of these medical problems.  No history does not mean that
>these conditions don't exist.  Individuals, tragically including 
>Morgan Jones, may not know that they have a heart problem or 
>hypertension that could be triggered into a potentially fatal attack 
>by MDMA's sympathomimetic effects.  These effects, shared with such 
>stimulants as methamphetamine and cocaine, include the shrinking of 
>blood vessels (vasoconstriction) and can elevate blood pressure to
>dangerous levels for those who are at risk.  The number of 
>individuals who are at such risk and do now know it may be
>statistically small, but who wants to be a statistic?  There may be
>more chambers in the gun, but does anyone really want to pull a
>chemical trigger when the result may well be death or permanent
>disability?  We have found that some individuals, after ingesting
>MDMA, have a prolonged posthallucinogen perceptual disorder
>(PHPD) with significant neuropsychological impairment.  It has been
>suggested that the disorder is caused by MDMA induced impairment
>of the brain's serotonergic system.
>
>Individuals with a history of alcohol and other drug abuse are
>particularly at risk.  In a review of Nicholas Saunders book, 
>"E is for Ecstasy," in the "Journal of Psychoactive Drugs,"
>Volume 26(3), 1994, Richard Seymour had the following to say:
>
>"Saunders has not obscured the downside of MDMA, but one thing
>workers in the drug treatment and recovery field are apt to find
>alarming is his lack of understanding regarding the nature of
>addiction, and the message that this may communicate to individuals
>who are at risk for addictive disease.  According to Saunders, 
>"A drug is considered addictive if physical withdrawal symptoms 
>occur when a regular user stops taking it.  MDMA is not addictive 
>by this definition..."  Such a misunderstanding of addiction was 
>one of the factors that led to widespread cocaine use in the United 
>States in the general belief that because cocaine did not produce 
>the same withdrawal found with heroin and barbiturates, it was not 
>an addictive drug.  Addiction is now generally thought to be a
>progressive disease, characterized by compulsion, loss of control, 
>and continued use of a substance in spite of adverse consequences, 
>and by that definition, MDMA can be addictive.
>
>"Another point of alarm is the concept that MDMA can be used by
>individuals to self-treat their addiction to other drugs, such as 
>heroin or alcohol.  While some psychoactive drugs are used 
>therapeutically in drug detoxification, such as the use of 
>phenobarbital taper to reduce the danger of life-threatening 
>seizures during alcohol and sedative withdrawal, the self-treatment 
>of addiction with other drugs is what the recovering community calls, 
>"changing seats on the Titanic."  Switching from the use of one 
>psychoactive drug to another does nothing to alleviate addiction, 
>and in fact may make matters worse by increasing the scope of the 
>addiction to include the new drug and reinforcing the addict's 
>rationale for denial."
>
>While there are obviously dangers and concerns, there are also 
>some major public misconceptions about MDMA.  MDMA has often been 
>confused in the media with the heroin-like designer drugs, such as
>fentanyl analogs, that have been responsible for opioid overdoes,
>and with an illicit demerol analog that contained an impurity that
>caused a Parkinson's disease-like paralysis in its users.  One of the
>most persistent misconceptions, and one we hear often at the Haight
>Ashbury Free Clinics, is that MDMA somehow "drains spinal fluid."
>
>While we are both against the legalization of any further
>psychoactive drugs at this time, we do feel that legitimate clinical
>research on such substances as MDMA should be encouraged.  In the
>past, we have gone on record advocating the adoption of a treatment
>research schedule that would allow this to take place outside the
>sanctions for illicit manufacture and sale to the general public.
>Without adequate research in controlled settings, much concerning
>MDMA and other outlawed substances remains a question mark,
>creating a public health danger and making it difficult to assess 
>the full spectrum of risks involved in their use.
>
>Sincerely,
>David E. Smith, M.D.
>Richard B. Seymour, M.A.
>January 18, 1996
>
>
>                  ******************************
>
>P.S. by Peter Jones:
>
>If you are in the Bay Area, you may want to communicate
>with the Haight Ashbury Free Clinics for information
>about drugs, or for help with a problem.  Their address:
>
>The Haight Ashbury Free Clinics, Inc.  
>409 Clayton Street
>San Francisco, CA 94117
>415-487-3688
>FAX: 415-621-7354
>

All very well and good, Bruce, but you still have not backed down from
saying -- outright -- that MDMA had nothing to do with all the recent
deaths in Britain.

I think that, unless other evidence is brought forward, we have to stipulate
that this the case.  The fact is, clinically, there is some (if very small)
risk of death from the use of MDMA.  And the reasoning of those who deny it
is suspect in the eyes of the media and, more importantly, among all of us
who are concerned with these issues, regardless of the cogency of the
argument put forth.

phred

Actually Phred there are two sides to this coin that are just as stubborn:

The media says MDMA CAUSED the deaths.

Eisner says MDMA is as safe as aspirin ( which any reasonable person won't
believe and rightly so. )

Both are lost in their own hype which is a sad fact of the WOD.... two armies
sitting in their trenches each praying to the same God to help them win a
"just war"  and bring Motherhood and apple pie back to the table of all true
Americans....

  And of course, voices of reason such as yours which say very likely that
MDMA could have been one of the contributing factors.... which means that a
whole plethora of things went wrong including perhaps health risk factors,
heat, MDMA, lack of water, low blood sugar, poor overall health , other 
drugs being used etc. The truth if it were found ( but first it would 
have to be looked for and neither side is really looking for truth ) is
probably a combination INCLUDING MDMA use.

  I'm not willing to side with the media because that just fuels the morally
corrupt WOD. Nor will I take the position that MDMA is safe....


  But I do predict that the drug being used by too many ravers that will be
MOST regretted long after MDMA is forgotten is none other than TOBACCO.

Hey all

Well, decided at the last minute to run off to Spundae, not too bad all 
considering!  When I first got there, the vibe was kinda meat-markety, 
you know, all those big buff college guys who run around with no shirts 
on & perfect hair?  Bleah!  Not my style at all.  But there was a nice 
mixture of pretty cool people, including those i came with, that helped 
balance that out a bit.  The overall feel was pretty clubby, but for a 
club it was pretty good.  There were four rooms with varying kinds of 
music, my fave was the big back room with the serious deep house & 
lasers a-blazin.  Considering the number of people there, it wasn't too 
badly ventilated, altho it got awful hot while actually dancing.  One 
really nice thing about the place was the fact that it had a big patio 
in the back that was entirely outdoors & it was very cool & refreshing 
to just hang for a while after sweating up a big disgusting storm!  The 
chill room was pretty cool in its own way, fat leather (vinyl?) couches 
and a fireplace!  Talk about ambience!  The floor was not very well set 
up for sitting down on (no rugs, etc) but the couches (of which there 
were many) were really cool.  Later in the evening, 4 am or so, a 
really good vibe got going in the chill-room, everybody was dancing to 
the wacky shit they were playing, everything from disco-y stuff to rap 
to all kinds of nameless boogy music.  Took off about 5 am, feeling 
energetic & happy that I could go dance & have a good time after all, I 
was kind of unsure when i first showed up.  I guess it sort of depends 
on your expectations, I certainly had NO expectations of finding a 
Harmony or Chrysalis or whatever, so I obviously was not disappointed 
in that way.  In *this* kind of situation, all I really need is at 
least some of the people to be cool, & some really kick-ass music; if 
it gets me dancing in spite of myself, I'm usually ok.

See ya'll

Shawna

Yes, the usual optomistic me is inspired to some criticism today.

After reflecting upon my weekend, I'd have to say that the highlight was 
teh new moon party simply because the crowd factor was ridiculous!

First of all there was Harmony - a really truely  great bunch of people - 
but the party was held in the Acme *again* and there were just TOO MANY 
PEOPLE - *AGAIN*!

Then SUnday night was Spundae and it was crazy the numbers of people in 
that building.  How the HELL can you have any kind of fun when you have 
to squeeze in and about through people to get anywhere and you are 
always getting stepped on or elbowed  or some big sweaty guy's back is 3 
inches from your face or some blonde's hair constantly swinging in your 
nose while you are trying to dance in a room where you can barely 
breathe because of too much smoke, heat and humidity?!?!?

I was nearly SICK just walking through the second floor of Harmony.  I 
just do not have fun in these kinds of conditions.  I mean all the 
people are really great as people, but as bodies, there are just too 
many!! I'm tired as hell of paying 10 - 15 bucks  only to sit all night 
long in a chill room to escape the crowds and heat.  That is not why I 
go to raves.  I go first and foremost to hear some great music on a nice 
sound system and to be able to DANCE.       

You know, I would much rather pay extra money for my ticket and have less 
people than pay only few dollars and have too many people.  The promoters 
have to get more people in when the ticket price is less so that they can
cover their costs. Am I not correct in assuming this?  I'm just 
*extremely* tired of this situation.

Bitch mode now off....

love,
Amy

On Mon, 19 Feb 1996, Bruce Ehrlich - Mindmedia wrote:

> What drugs laws do is

> The greatest misunderstanding are 1) about the differences between drugs
> (MDMA and LSD are not addictive in most people for example and are far safer
> than alcohol and amphetamine which are addictive. And 2)confusion between
> intelligent use and abuse. When these boundaries are obscured by
> misinformation, the stage is set for much tragedy which has played itself in
> the world during the year of the New Prohibition.  

And you do little to help the situation. Fighting propaganda with 
propaganda does little to get to the elusive truths. How do you know that 
the deaths attributed to MDMA in England were not at least in part due to 
the consumption of MDMA, and more importantly what medical credentials do 
you posses to make a definitve judgement?

> Many of the warning given by Smith and Seymour are also given in my book.
> Their list is a bit longer but I believe Rick Doblin, in the following
> forward post discusses this quite well. However my book is not used as a
> textbook in classes in intelligent drug use in high schools and adult
> schools by most teachers. If it were, MDMA would be a much safer drug
> because my book recommends that people be taught more intelligent drug use
> in schools and in special centers, and that this training be funded by
> replacing the current tough laws, which insure impure drugs will be consumed
> by uninformed youth.

It is not the place of the school to teach drug use or non-use. That job 
should be left up to the HOPEFULLY but not often enough well-informed 
*PARENT* It is they that are responsible for their children ultimately; 
not you, and certainly not the schools. There are a lot, a LOT of lies 
perpetrated by programs like D.A.R.E., however given the options of 
either teaching kids drug use, and scaring them into not using them, I 
choose the latter as the lesser of the two evils. How many children have you 
heard of that have died because the did *not* use an illicit substance? 
  
> I urge everyone has posted to read my book, Ecstasy: The MDMA Story (Ronin
> Publishing Berkeley, 1989, 1994). Hundreds have people have told me that
> this book has changed their lives for the better. I believe that the
> ignorance must be replaced by knowledge, and that so-called experts like
> Seymour and Smith, who take their money from the Government's NIDA, try a
> different strategy...and they won't have so many young people strung out on
> methamphetamine and heroin because they can't get clean MDMA or even MDMA at
> all. And believe me, despite the urgings of these so-called experts, youth
> will continue to experiment. Other cultures employ wise teachers and shamen
> to train their youth in ritual, intelligent and moderate use of
> mind-changing compounds. Why don't we make the world safer for them?

"Buy my book, buy my book, BUY MY BOOK!" I for one get the fucking point of 
your thinly-veiled Eisner-mercial. I'm not buying your damn book, your 
bumper stickers, or anything else from you. At least have the decency to 
preface your self-promotion with the words BSP(Blatant Self-Promotion) in 
the title of the message.  

You are right, ignorance must be replaced by knowledge. You, like the 
anti-drug camp, have an agenda. You are not an unbiased source of 
information. Please do not attempt to pass yourself off as one. So I 
guess we can read your propaganda, read the anti-drug propaganda, and 
find once again that the truth is somewhere in the middle. Your 
"knowledge" like mine or anyone elses is tainted by your agenda.   

If anyone has half a brain, they will search out the truth for 
themselves, instead of mindlessly using your "truth" between the glossy 
covers as their source of information. Ultimately it is my health. 
my well-being, and my *LIFE* I'd be damned before I took you as an 
unbiased source of information or advised anyone to do the same.  

 
                                        Black Adder


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 19 17:01:32 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA27486; Mon, 19 Feb 1996 17:01:32 -0800
Received: from ix9.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA27478; Mon, 19 Feb 1996 17:01:29 -0800
Received: from  by ix9.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id RAA29067; Mon, 19 Feb 1996 17:00:55 -0800
Date: Mon, 19 Feb 1996 17:00:55 -0800
Message-Id: <199602200100.RAA29067@ix9.ix.netcom.com>
From: sequoia1@ix.netcom.com (Chris Chervin )
Subject: A Positive note for E
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A positive note for #

I am living proof that E can be used to quit harmful drug abuse.  I was 
a tabacoo smoker for 6 years smoking 10-15 cigs a day.  I tried 
nicotine patches as well as  will-power to quit on many occasions. But 
I could not seem to break the habit.  An E experience at the Gathering 
in 1994 enabled me to break the habit easily and without any withdrawl 
smptoms what-so-ever!

The night I quit was not planned either.  I went to the party without 
the slightest clue that I was about to stop smoking.  While it was 
definetly true that I wanted to rid the habit (as I had tried in the 
past) I still figured it would be a few years before I could.  Well, an 
amazing realization that night made it very clear why I was on this 
planet and very clear that cigarettes were not condusive to my mission. 
In an expression of joy I threw my fresh pack of smokes on the floor 
and shed the habit.

The amazing thing is that it has been so increadibly easy to quit!  I 
did not and have not fiended for a cigarette since than and felt no 
shakes, sickness, headaches or other physical symptoms the first weeks 
after I quit.  Infact I was on a very nice after-glow for some time.

This experience is just one of the many amazing and LIFE-Bennifiting 
experiences that I owe to this drug.  I will never in words be able to 
express the wonderful things it CAN do.  On the other hand I think the 
risks are quite obvious.  Particulary the fact that one does not KNOW 
what is in that pill.  Mainly for that reason I choose to refrain from 
it now.  The things I have learned will be with me and sobriety is the 
new teacher.

love chris

Hello all,

The good ole' Acme building.  Truly a most perfect place for a party.  
If only 200-300 people are going.  Any more than that and it just 
outright sucks.  All the small rooms are great for change of scenery 
but you can't enjoy it if its overcrowded.  

I'm not sure but I don't think promoters can afford to use the space 
unless the sell too many tickets.  Which is a bummer because a small 2 
or 300 person party there would truly be the bomb!

I will most likely do my best to avoide any partys at that site.  While 
I can't expect all promoters to give us the chance to know where the 
site is prior to buying tickets I would hope that Gateway, Fnf, 
Harmony, and any other Cool promoters begin to "warn" us if the site 
they secured is the infamous Acme building.  This might scare off many 
party-goers (like me) and thus leave a less crowded space.  Will you 
warn us?  

Thanks to Gateway and Harmony for the many wonderful parties you have 
thrown and will throw in the future.  Much love and respect.

love chris

Dear Friends & Family,

On Mon, 19 Feb 1996 Black Adder shared (in part):

> How many children have you 
> heard of that have died because they did *not* use an illicit substance? 

And I would like to venture in response that comparing the number of 
adolescent deaths from Exstasy to the number of adolescent suicides each 
year might provide, if not a direct answer, at least a further question: 
 
How many of those young people might have found, like our own Brian 
Darkness (not that he was necessarily suicidal) new reason to live had they 
been able to try this drug?  

Unfortunately there is no way to keep such statistics, so we'll never 
know, but my feeling is that the possibility of lives saved should not be 
overlooked in this discussion of the value or merits of MDMA.
	
For the record, I do not have any financial or other stake in the matter 
other than that of a satisfiEd customer.  :)

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

Spundae said that Jam and Spoon were performing live.  Actually, it
was the female vocalist from Jam and Spoon only.  Hey, who needs
to fly out those crazy Germans to tweak their synths when you have
a vocalist who can sing just as well over DAT who lives right here in
SF!

Now, I don't mind live perfomances with some DAT in them... but a completely
canned perfomance is kind of unforgivable.  They had two guys with keyboards
and an acoustic guitar air-banding to the music.  One of the keyboards looked
like one of those toy ones you get at Circuit City.  The least they
could have done was plug the keyboards in so it might just acutally look
like they were performing.  The big keyboard had no Audio or MIDI connections..
the toy keyboard did not have they power plugged in.  Again, at least
they could have put a scant amount of effort into making it look sorta
real.  Saying "Jam and Spoon performing live" was an extreme lie by
Spundae.

Mad last night was 100% better.  A nice, clean, non-smokey, cool room
with lotsa blacklights and cool video projections... a clean sound system...
and great music!  A live perfomance offered by... by... well, I forgot
who exactly was performing, but it was really cool.  Probably better than
a real Jam and Spoon show would have been.  So many cool people I knew showed
up for Mad, including a ton of SFravers.  Of course this great of a
club does come at a price... a whopping three dollars :)  I can't imagine
a better way to end my weekend.

-troy

> Amy, why do you live in sacramento?

Well, because I have to finish college.  I live with my parents and go to 
sac state - by living at home it saves me ALOT of money and right now I'm 
saving so that when I graduate in December I can move to SF.  Believe me, 
it is tough to go home when I feel like my real home is over there.  Most 
of my friends are there and I am there 2 or 3 weekends a month.  By the 
time I finish school and begin looking for work, not to mention FINDING a 
job before I graduate, and finding roomates (which is already starting to 
happen) and finding a place to live with them, the time is actually going 
to fly!!  I'll be down again this weekend for the F&F daytime party!

love,
Amy

Subject: Re: MDMA USE
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960220033859.12023D-100000@apollo>

On Tue, 20 Feb 1996, Starchild wrote:

> Dear Friends & Family,
> 
> On Mon, 19 Feb 1996 Black Adder shared (in part):
> 
> > How many children have you 
> > heard of that have died because they did *not* use an illicit substance? 
> 
> And I would like to venture in response that comparing the number of 
> adolescent deaths from Exstasy to the number of adolescent suicides each 
> year might provide, if not a direct answer, at least a further question: 
>  
> How many of those young people might have found, like our own Brian 
> Darkness (not that he was necessarily suicidal) new reason to live had they 
> been able to try this drug?  

Please do not take my comments as a comdemnation of Ecstacy. Far from it. 
However, I think that institutionalized drug classes are a very, VERY bad 
idea, and have no place in an educational system. An individual student 
being able to go to a counselor or some such person and getting honest, 
un-biased information, yes. Teaching drug-use to an entire population, no.  
There are a lot of people out there that simply should not take drugs.  

> Unfortunately there is no way to keep such statistics, so we'll never 
> know, but my feeling is that the possibility of lives saved should not be 
> overlooked in this discussion of the value or merits of MDMA.

And how many would have been saved from seeking professional help? If we 
are getting tangental we might also want to include those unquantifiable 
numbers in our discussion.

I would never, ever, deny that use of MDMA has changed many peoples lives 
for the better, including my own. However, Bruce Ehrlichs self-important 
suggestion that his book be used as a text book in schools which teach 
children to use drug was the issue. In my opinion, a very poor suggestion 
indeed...  

                                            Black Adder

Precedence: bulk

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 20 Feb 1996 04:46:06 -0500
From: Peter A Denitto <pad35295@PEGASUS.CC.UCF.EDU>
To: Multiple recipients of list CONSFUN <CONSFUN@ucf1vm.cc.ucf.edu>
Subject: Internet Cleanup

Subject: it's cleaning time again!

please redistribute this important information to everyone likely to
be impacted by this event.


 *** Attention ***

 It's that time again!

 As many of you know, each leap year the internet must be shut down for 24
 hours in order to allow us to clean it.  The cleaning process, which
 eliminates dead email and inactive ftp, www and gopher sites, allows for
 a better-working and faster internet.

 This year, the cleaning process will take place from 12:01 a.m. GMT on
 Feb. 29 until 12:01 a.m. GMT on March 1.  During that 24-hour period,
 five powerful internet-crawling robots situated around the world will
 search the internet and delete any data that they find.

 In order to protect your valuable data from deletion we ask that you do
 the following:

 1.  Disconnect all terminals and local area networks from their internet
 connections.

 2.  Shut down all internet servers, or disconnect them from the internet.

 3.  Disconnect all disks and hardrives from any connections to the
internet.

 4.  Refrain from connecting any computer to the internet in any way.

 We understand the inconvenience that this may cause some internet users,
 and we apologize.  However, we are certain that any inconveniences will
 be more than made up for by the increased speed and efficiency of the
 internet, once it has been cleared of electronic flotsam and jetsam.

 We thank you for your cooperation.

 Kim Dereksen
 Interconnected Network Maintenance staff
 Main branch, Massachusetts Institute of Technology

 Sysops and others:  Since the last internet cleaning, the number of
 internet users has grown dramatically.  Please assist us in alerting the
 public of the upcoming internet cleaning by posting this message where
 your users will be able to read it.  Please pass this message on to other
 sysops and internet users as well.  Thank you.

------------ Forwarded Message ends here ------------

>Yes, the usual optomistic me is inspired to some criticism today.
>
>After reflecting upon my weekend, I'd have to say that the highlight was
>teh new moon party simply because the crowd factor was ridiculous!
>
>First of all there was Harmony - a really truely  great bunch of people -
>but the party was held in the Acme *again* and there were just TOO MANY
>PEOPLE - *AGAIN*!
>
>Then SUnday night was Spundae and it was crazy the numbers of people in
>that building.  How the HELL can you have any kind of fun when you have
>to squeeze in and about through people to get anywhere and you are
>always getting stepped on or elbowed  or some big sweaty guy's back is 3
>inches from your face or some blonde's hair constantly swinging in your
>nose while you are trying to dance in a room where you can barely
>breathe because of too much smoke, heat and humidity?!?!?
>
>I was nearly SICK just walking through the second floor of Harmony.  I
>just do not have fun in these kinds of conditions.  I mean all the
>people are really great as people, but as bodies, there are just too
>many!! I'm tired as hell of paying 10 - 15 bucks  only to sit all night
>long in a chill room to escape the crowds and heat.  That is not why I
>go to raves.  I go first and foremost to hear some great music on a nice
>sound system and to be able to DANCE.
>
>You know, I would much rather pay extra money for my ticket and have less
>people than pay only few dollars and have too many people.  The promoters
>have to get more people in when the ticket price is less so that they can
>cover their costs. Am I not correct in assuming this?  I'm just
>*extremely* tired of this situation.
>
>Bitch mode now off....
>
>love,
>Amy
>
>---------------
>|   _  ,/|    |
>|  '\`o O'    |
>|   =(_^_)=   |         Amy Starkey
>|     |U|     |         sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu
>|     | |     |
>---------------

I think that all of the promoters and partygoeres in the scene pretty much
agree that Acme sucks.  It's too small, it's too hot, it costs too much,
etc. etc.
However, the reason why it keeps on getting used is because quite simply,
there are no other spaces. The only place that you can legally throw a
non-2000 person rave is at a club, where you have to serve alcohol or
charge $20 a head, which a lot of people are unwilling to do. Until Da
Mayor makes good on his campaign promises to make it easier to get permits
(his son is a hip-hop DJ), promoters are stuck with the Acme, and other
small,  hot, illegal venues.  Not that illegality is really that bad, but
you try convincing the owner of a warehouse to let you throw an all night,
illegal, loud, drug-ridden party at his space.  Oh well, space availability
(like everything else), comes in waves, so maybe soon a whole bunch of
spaces will open up, and everyone will live happily ever after.

-john

Brian, 
 
if you want a more clear view of what I am saying........simply put..... 
 
I don't give a fuck what lousy drugs you do or did !!!!! nor do I wish to
hear about it.   (I can only speak for myself of course), and why do you
insist on talking about personal drug experiences on sfraves. 
While we all know that raving CAN involve drugs, it doesn't mean it HAS to.

 
It's posts like yours that make us all look like we are a drug induced
community, we are not.........and even if we were........that kind of talk
should be kept private, or discussed in a more responsible manner....I'm
sorry, I am new to sfraves, maybe I'm out of line.........but I just feel
we have many many subjects that relate to the rave scene that are not drug
related..........as far as debating the pro's and cons of a specific
drug.........i.e.... M.D.M.A.....this is far more appropriate, than
discussing PERSONAL experiences........and good and bad drug stories, If
you are having trouble understanding my post, perhaps you should do less
drugs..........sorry I had to say it!!! 
 
As far as smart drinks, dancing, and dance circles, what the fuck is the
coralation to your post about your bad experience of drugs.....or my post
stating that it's not the wisest thing to be talking about..........That
makes no sense to me.......don't get so defensive, just use your COMMON
SENSE......... 
 
I feel I'm getting too negative in my post about not talking about personal
drug experiences........can some-one else shed light on this
subject.......after all isn't one of the rules of sfraves......NO DRUG
TALK.........is debate about drugs DRUG TALK, or is it merely
debate.........HELP ME TO UNDERSTAND OUR POSITION........moonpup

sorry if my posts seemed hostile, I was probably a little out of
line.....I'm interested in hearing about many different things that relate
to rave lifestyle too, I guess it just seemed rather odd to hear about
someones bad drug experience (of the night before) 
 
I guess if it had related to an old story that had a point to make, or had
meaning in the form of "and the moral of the story is" etc.....I could see
justify-ing a drug related story.......... but to just blurt out that you
had bad drugs the night before, doesn't seem to say much......after all, we
all from time to time have done good and bad drugs....but I feel each of us
do different drugs for our own different reasons. It's of a personal
nature, not something to be discussed amonsgt 450 people + 
 
.... I mean if we all posted how our drug experiences were every weekend, I
would feel we had taken a bad turn somewhere. However it is somewhat a
subject that relates to the rave lifestyle, so I apologize to Brian and any
other SFRaver who I have insulted, if my post seemed to be of a negative
nature....it was not my intention to be so critical or closed minded to the
feelings of the rest of you.....I humbly ask your forgiveness 
 
and as far as rules..........your right .....there are no rules....are
there ??? sorry again....

Hi all!

	I've been in the south bay area for about a year now, but I haven't
had the time to go out much on the weekends until lately, and none of
my current friends are into the rave scene, so....

	I wanted to go to teknotica last Sat, but never got a call back
about where/how much/etc. Can anyone suggest upcoming raves for someone with
interests like mine:

	Hard trance/hard techno - BPM over everything else
	Detroit

Actually, I guess most types (except ambient) are OK, but those are my two
favorites. Thanks for any help people can give me, and I hope to start
meeting some of you in person (I'm a very tall light skinned italian,
and I tend to favor fairly skimpy leather gear - if you see a girl with a
stylized "S" branded on her rear end, it's me)

		Thanks!

This one was great! I have only been to a half dozen raves or so, but
this was the best yet. Everyone was friendly and open and I really had
a great time. It was super hot, causing me to spend more time in the
chill room than usual, but that was okay. I appreciated the Hamony
peoples efforts to make the extra exits available. Even with someone
there to open the garage door in an emergency, that building could
get hairy to exit. Thanks to all of you who went for making it a great
experience and special thanks to those who put it on. The time spent
on signs/decorations/etc really made a difference. 

Jim Ausman

Precedence: bulk

Moonpup asks:
>and as far as rules.......your right .....there are no rules....are
>there ???

There are a set of guidelines issued to all who join the sfraves
mailing list.  The only hard "rule" that I can think of is that the
list not be used to carry out blatently illegal activities (i.e.
drug dealing).  But even this rule gets bent on a regular basis,
since many of the raves promoted here can be considered illegal.

Sfraves is mostly self-governing, with Brian Behlendorf, owner of
the hardware, as the final arbitrator of the activities here.
He can be reached at brian@hyperreal.com.

The debate of what exactly is approprite to post here is a
neverending one.  A lot of people use filters on their mailers to
block out the posts of certain people, or with certain strings in
the subject header.  Others just use the "delete" key alot.

In my view, there will always be people who abuse the live-and-let-live 
nature of this list.  People who talk about specific time and places
where they buy and sell drugs is one example of abuse, IMO.  People
who *habitually* blather on about non-rave-related personal issues
is another.  Most of us can sense when we're pissing people off, so
things rarely get of hand.  Allowing for the abuse of freedom is one 
of the prices we pay for it.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

hey everyone,

  four nights going out.  i dont usually post but thought id
give a brief opinion on the four parties

Harmony:  I was upset that Terry Mullan was not spinning, since
 he rocked my world at the gathering, but a good party after
 4 am when the place cleared out a bit.  It was too jammed
 before then.  I loved Harry Who's set. Who is this guy!?!
 book him more please!

Organic:  A good party. not amazing, but good. DJ Dan was Dan.
 But DJ Sneak was amazing period.  The most interesting set
 i have heard spun in a long time. i loved the way he just
 took control of the vibe and made it work his way.

Spundae: another good party. Mark Lewis from LA was my favorite
 dj of the night. but it was also cool the vartiety of music that
 was available.  and i had never been to 1015 before.  Big props
 to the sound (except in the bottom room) for being not to loud
 (MY POOR EARS!!)

Mad: Was nice also.  has not had the crazy fun vibe for a few 
 weeks now.  Andy;s set was really good.
 i really like the new music.


but enough parting for me until Derrick May comes to town :)

peace all and take care,

doug ) ( doug@hyperreal.com

On Mon, 19 Feb 1996, CHRISTINA ANN-MARIE HOAG wrote:

> the reason why the beat does not have any turntables is because everytime 
> they got a new needle, somebody stole it.  Or at least that is the story 
> that I was told in December as to why there were no turntables there?  
> Has anybody else heard any other reasons????

	Most any place that is not run for Djs or people looking for
techno (or not run by people who like techno and therefore do not
understand how much shit is out there and how picky one's ear can be to
it...) seems to have stopped letting people drop needles on records before
buying them.  Many of these places give you a full 50% - 80% when you
return vinyl that has been played once. Rasputin's in Berkeley (last
summer) said they were tired of vinyl going to waste because people who 
scratch it while listening - so I asked them to drop needles on it for me 
and they chuckled. Now, after watching a large stock of vinyl sit, get 
old, and warpin the heat, I hear you can listen at pre-arranged times... 
I wonder if their little scam didn't work out...

dave

Thank you new moon kids.  The opening ritual by Guillermo, Raphael and Dale
really grounded the energy.  Todd & Heather gave us an organic juice bar. 
It was yummy.  A lot of love went into the party, thank you everyone.  The
generosity of everyone covered our costs, & that felt really good.  We
don't mean to be elitist, we didn't post the # to avoid an ACME crowd
situation.  Our # is (415)267-3076.  Call each new moon to find out what's
going on.  Next month we'll probably hold a small outdoor ritual.  Love to
everyone, especially Ann & Gregg.  You make it happen.   
 
Love & Peace

but the reason I joined is that my mate Rob is coming over to your part of 
the world next Wednesday.

plays mental hard and slinky psychedelic trance (my review). He's looking 
for places to play and good record shops I guess so if any of you can point 
him in the right direction he would be most grateful. If anyone would like 
a copy of his last demo tape (which is absolutely mental (again my review)

BY YOUR COMMAND;

        These Are the Stories Of The California Highway Patrol, told from
the other side(Just da Facts, House Nation)

        Diary of a Bust, Part 2, Jail

        Date: 01/04/96

        Time & Conditions: Approximately 4:00am, on a Dark, 
        Drizzling, Thursday Morning

        Location: East Bay Bridge; East Bound, Lower Deck

        Vehicle Type: 1986 Chevy Station Wagon
                                aka The Yellow Submarine


        They arrived at the police station shortly, and they took him out of
the car. The one officer asked Bob are you comfortable with your arms like
that? Bob replied, yes of course I am can't you tell I'm weird officer, and
at that moment they entered the jail.......

Part 2, JAIL:

        The officer chuckled at Bob's comment as the 3 made their way
through the dark maze like halls which are 850 Bryant Street, the Hall of
Injustice.
    
        The first stop, the super breatalizer room. Where Bob once again had
to blow into the tube twice so that they could double double check to see if
Bob was drunk on alcohol. Or just it case to see if he had drank some in the
back of the police cruiser on the way, no doubt. Bob twice again blew two
big zero's, and received more perplexed looks of disappointment & dismay
from the two officers.

        The three then proceeded down the hall to an area where Bob was to
be unhand cuffed and given more sobriety testing once again. Once again Bob
complied with their repeated inane requests of counting out loud, guessing
when 30 seconds had pasted, standing on one foot while having his eyes
closed & touching his nose & ...etc. Once again Bob seemed to pass all the
tests, yet no indication was given even at his request.

        The officer then proceeded to take my pulse and blood pressure to
see if it was elevated from the so called speed or cocaine Bob had taken.
Bob's BP and pulse were taken sitting, standing, & on both arms the results
being pretty much the same; 110/70 pulse 80. Bob responded with tremendous
glee, pretty high officer for someone doing speed or cocaine; his comment
reeking of sarcasm. Another perplexed, and dismayed look filled both
officers eye's.

        Bob was then told to either submit to a piss or a blood test, his
choice or be fined and/or banned from operating a motor vehicle in the state
of California for up to a year. Regarding the choice of tests Bob thought to
himself, are they for real, I get a choice, hehe, I'll take the piss test
responded Bob, but only if I have to. The officer once again looked dismayed
and perplexed and said that because we know your doing drugs you have no
choice Bob, it's either one or the other. Bob thought ok, but hell if I'm
going to give them my blood. Shit they can tell way more info with that than
they can my urine, and chances are nothing has metabolized yet.

        So Bob, along with the male officer walked into room that smelled
like human feces, containing a toilet that had seemed like it had never ever
been cleaned, yuk. Of course due to Bob's nervousness he couldn't go to the
bathroom. So the male officer while watching turned on the facet which
started the water flowing, which the sound of, according to the officer
helped people pee. It worked and Bob proceeded to pee. They usually tell you
so that you can prevent/minimize contaminants to allow the stream to start
and then place the tiny glass container into the stream for collection. Bob,
being the smart ass that he is, placed the container clumsily and
immediately in front of the stream. Then handing the wet container back to
the officer, here ya go said Bob, adding after the officer received the
container, in a serious tone, but secretly joking with him, Bob made the
statement, oh by the way my Doctor thinks I have HIV, the officer then
almost dropped the urine.

        They then proceed to the next stop, the body search room. Bob and
the male officer entered another disgusting room with no place to sit down
and Bob was asked to take off all his clothes, everything. Bob complied and
sneered at the officer. Bob removed his clothes, & while standing there butt
naked the officer asked him to turn around and of course bend over. Bob once
again complied while hearing the latex glove go snap. There was a moment of
pain and Bob was told to get dressed again less his boots, belt, hair tie
...etc, leaving him with his red shirt, & black vinyl plants. Bob was then
instructed to sit on a bench with about 10 prostitutes, while they went
through his belongings.

        The property people seemed to be having the time of their lives with
Bob's stuff, holding up the collar and leash making barking noises. Bob was
later told he made the SF Police's property departments night for having the
most unusual stuff. Bob of course took great pride in this, it being SF and
everything.

        It was about 6am when Bob was then taken to the drunk tank and
remained there to about 8:30am. It must have been a busy night because both
holding and drunk tanks were filled with about 30 people each. These cells
were also disgustingly dirty with jail roaches so brave they just walked
around where ever, & when ever, E-Bee Milton would have loved it. Bob shared
the cell with the very charming company of 30 or so men ranging from a
freak(Bob), a suit, to a few gays, to homeless people with lice on them,
lovely. Bob however was asked if he wanted breakfast, Bob responded what ya
got; the guard responded jail food boy. Ahhh no thanks, replied Bob, like he
was supposed to know what jail food was.

        Around 8:30am everyone was moved to the holding & processing cell,
that was just as gross as the other cell, roaches included. Then a fight
almost broke out between two men. The fight was over the fact that the one
man hand accidently woken up the other, Bob thought to himself, ahhh this
must be the entertainment for the morning. The experience was begriming to
way on Bob, he had to keep saying to himself that, I know I'm getting out
soon, repeatedly.

        After about an hour in there Bob was requested to come to the final
processing area where he was finger printed and had mug shots taken. Note, I
will be happy to post copies to the net to interested parties when I get
them back. After that Bob was given back his stuff, his nice leather
backpack with the alien sticker on it torn by the officers and unusable,
thinking to himself, fuckers I'll eat them alive in court. He was then
handed a summons and a court date stating his MISDEMEANORS charges and are
as follows:

1.     R201168 01621613 BKD 23152(A) VC/M;NOW 23152(A)VC/M;
        DUI ALCOHOL/DRUGS;DEFSTATUS COJ1;ARR 010496/0400;INCN
138900196; ENTERED BY 792

2.     R201169 01621613 BKD 11550HS/M;NOW 1155HS/M; USE/UNDER
INFLUENCE OF CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE

3.     R201170 01621613 BKD 23222(B)VC/M;NOW 23222(B)VC/M;
POSESSION OF MARIJ >1 OZ WHILE DRIVING

        Court date 2/01/95:

        Bob walked out of the police station turned around and proceeded to
flip the station the bird, and got into a cab heading to Oak Town in order
to retrieve his friends car; which he did successfully, but $160.00

        Make sure you stay tuned for the exciting & climatic conclusion to
our story, Diary of a Bust, Part 3; Court. Look out OJ!!!!!!!







       


31 seconds and we're going for autosequence start.................
See ya's in space, 4,3,2.1.......darknEs^2 out>>>>-----____......

To everyone who went to Harmony:

I love you all!!!  Thanks so much for making this one of the best parties
of my short raving life (started in September '94, at a Jeremiah party).
To everyone I met, I'm glad to have you in the family, and hope/know we'll
see each other again.  Sorry I wasn't more talkative, but I found myself
way too blissful to speak at times.  I could barely get myself to dance!
Then there was the heat...but we've all heard plenty about that.
One young guy told a friend that I (of all people) was the one who inspired
him to embrace the "scene", and that made me feel soooooo gooooood!  All of
you, even those I didn't meet, contributed to a very beautiful vibe, and so
much love & happiness that I'm still glowing! :)  I'm glad people liked my
SHROOMARAMA shirt, and my butterfly.  Thanks to a beautiful person who came
to us in the chill room early on, and gifted us with candy, toys, and
stickers.  I put a glittery heart on my butterfly, and felt that it
represented the inner me, shining my heart out for everyone in the center
of my butterfly, which is my metamorphosis into a beacon of love for
everyone!  Am I too happy or what?
See y'all next time...

Love & stuff,

- E

Eric P. Peterson
Financial Assistant
N&CS Materials Management
Synopsys Inc.

At 11:22 AM 2/21/96, Marc Fathauer wrote:
>A friend of mine whom I went to Organic with on Saturday has decided he MUST
>get a copy of the remix of the Eurthmics "Sweet Dreams" that he heard spun
>there.
>
>Please help-he's driving me crazy.......
>marcus@technologik.com

Try to convince him he really doesn't want it. Really. It's a super cheese
casio preset house track that throws all of the vocals from the original
over the top. It can sound ok mixed over something else, but on it's own
it's a bit lacking. It came out on white label, but I haven't seen any
around for a month or so. They did have 'em at Primal along with an even
cheesier house remake of some Doors song. Man, whoever did that Led
Zeppelin mix had no idea what he was starting.

For the definitive house/techno mix of "Sweet Dreams..." check the
Nightmare mix from 1991.

But then again, what do I know? Everyone seem to go crazy whenever it's
played. Just wait for my jungle remix of ABBA's "Dancing Queen"

Joe

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 21 15:00:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA19955; Wed, 21 Feb 1996 15:00:33 -0800

Message-Id: <199602212259.OAA12802@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, twaxx@netcom.com
Subject: some interesting psych stuff
Date: Wed, 21 Feb 96 14:59:15 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Interesting to note the long-standing ritual use of plant based
psychedelics in other cultures.

(this note forwarded without permission and without attribution)...

------- Forwarded Message

Tryptamines are a class of indole-ethanamine compounds (thus organic)
which are reknown for some of them being  potent hallucinogens. The
neurotransmitter serotonin is also a tryptamine. The most common (and
perhaps potent) hallucinogenic form is DMT (dimethyltryptamine or
N,N-dimethyl-1H-indole-3-ethanamine) .

Tryptamine  and DMT and its derivatives are naturally occurring
compounds. DMT, aMT, 5-OMe-DMT, beta carbolines, and bufotenine are
found in a variety of South American plants including species of
Myristicaceae (Virola species), Fabaceae (Anadenanthera or piptadenia
peregrina, Mimosa hostilis), Zygophillaceae (Pegonum harmala),
Malpighiaceae (Banisteriopsis species, Tetrapteris methystica),
Rubiaceae (Psychotria species) Apocyanaceae (Restonia amazonica), and
Acanthaceae (Justicia pectoralis).  Psilocin and psilocybin are
tryptamine derivatives and are found in many varieties of
hallucinogenic mushrooms. (Psilocybe, Gymnopilus, Panoeolus, Conocybe,
and Strophorius)

Ayahuasca is from a plant of the species Banisteria (Banisteriopsis
rusbyana). Banisteriopsis and Psychotria leaves are used to make a
hallucinogenic (or narcotic) drink known as ayahuasca (uasca), caapi,
yaje, or cipo in northern South American. The principal active
compounds are the alkaloid carbolines harmine, 3,4-dihydroharmine
(harmaline), and 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroharmine.

Virola snuff is known as yakee and yato in Columbia and parica, epena,
and nyakwana in Brazil. Anadenanthera snuff if known as cohaba and yopo
in the West Indies and  South American.  Mimosa hostilis roots are used
to make an hallucinogenic drink known as ajuca and vinho de Jurema in
eastern Brazil.    Bufotenine is also present in the skin glands and
venoms of frogs and toads of the genera Hyla, Letodactylus, Rana, and
Bufo and may be ingested if these creatures are licked, chewed, or
swallowed (a la Beavis and Butthead).

The hallucinogenic indolealkylamines have properties in common with
LSD, serotonin, (5-hydroxy- tryptamine), ergotamine, and
beta-carbolines (harmine). The pyrrole portion of the indole ring is
conjectured to be key to their hallucinogenic activity. These compounds
appear to act primarily by stimulating serotonin type 2 (5HT2)
receptors. Some compounds are partial 5HT receptor agonists or mixed
agonist-antagonists. They also can stimulate dopaminergic and
tryptaminergic receptors as well as inhibit  monoamine oxidases. 
Though these latter properties appear to be less important in their
pharmacological activity.

------- End of Forwarded Message

I would just like to say that I am glad that you have sparked another 
discussion  related to this topic.  No matter how many times it comes up, 
I like to hear about what people say.  It is a learning experience all 
the way around.  To ignore the juxtoposition of raves and ecstasy is 
silly.  I enjoyed the debate that both sides(for lack of a better word) put 
on, and have emerged with more conclusions of my own.

kc

kirstenc@uclink.berkeley.edu
