From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199602252008.MAA21341@netcom18.netcom.com>
Subject: FnF Anti-Freeze !
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 25 Feb 1996 12:08:35 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 4524      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


 SFRaves list]

 A grim weather report was dampening the chances for yesterday's 
Friends and Family daytime event at Point Molate :

SAN FRANCISCO BAY REGION

.TODAY...SHOWERS AND ISOLATED THUNDERSTORMS...POSSIBLY WITH SMALL
HAIL.  HIGHS UPPER 40S TO MID 50S. WEST WIND 10 TO 25 MPH.
.TONIGHT...NUMEROUS SHOWERS WITH ISOLATED EVENING THUNDERSTORMS. 
 LOWS 30S AND LOWER 40S. WESTERLY EVENING WIND 10 TO 25 MPH.

 Despite the predictions of the weathermen , the sun was (mostly)
shining above us , so Ethan said "GO!".

 The sound system was already unloaded by the time I got there at 
12:45PM . After a few drops fell from the sky, we decided to put
up my collapsible awning. ( After yesterday , I think I may buy 
another one that handles easier and is waterproof !)

 Music started on-time ! ( Someone please post the DJ sequence ).
Folks gradually arrived , despite the predictions of thunderstorms. 
We were making our own sweet techno thunder on the ground! 

 And the weather gods gave us a break, for a few hours . Looking 
across San Pablo Bay, it seemed that Mt. Tamalpias was sending an 
invisible cleaving ray up to the sky , parting the clouds so that 
they sailed to the north and south of us. Not another drop , even 
some sunshine slanting in through breaks in the clouds.

 At the other end of the park was the ambient music setup. Given 
the location and the difference in volume, it was overlooked by 
most folks , unless they were walking to the porta potty. Despite 
the worsening weather and a lack of a steady audience , DJs Andrew , 
Phred , Claire , et al persevered ! 

 The weather did worsen - at about 3:30 , rain drops started falling.
Then , the wind from the west increased dramatically - wind chill!
But we kept on dancing! Some folks discovered the intense sensual 
experience of dancing at the bayside edge of the park , leaning
into the frigid wind . It felt like flying! Just at that time, a 
flock of seagulls flew close to us over the beach as we danced at
the edge , enhancing the fantasy of being airborne 

 From somewhere ( Derek Capito? ) , two more canopies showed up to
protect the sound equipment and the ravers who were close enough to 
get under the canopies.

 I dug out my yellow rain jacket and put it on .What was happening 
with the ambient setup? I walked along the beach to their site on 
a childrens' play structure. They had already put up more blue tarps 
on the seaside of the structure , and the speakers were moved under 
the roof. It did seem like a jetty or some similar blockish seacraft, 
floating along on ambient/jungle seas , with strong westerly winds 
blowing in the sea spray. 

 I split my time between the dance site and the ambient site. Near
the end , despite the great view of the bay and the Marin County
highlands, I was seriously considering curling up in the cab of my
truck and waiting for the music to stop so I could help with
break down. The worst of the weather had departed by 7:00PM , but
it was getting colder. 

 I ended up in the top of the ambient "boat" , under the tarp -
someplace dry and wind free! But warm, but the wind chill was
reduced enough to let me recover. Claire's ambient music was 
entrancing - I got into some strange meditative mindset then. Maybe
pre-hypothermia ? It was a small special moment.

 I spent a short time after that hanging out on the "deck" near some
candles. Then , back to the dance area for a final warm up! About
30 people were still left of the maximum crowd of about 150 folks.
A haloed sliver of moon and the stars were above us - lights of
humanity along the bridge and across the bay. I danced and chatted
and danced. 

 The music faded out at about 8:20 PM. Break down went without
incident , and we left the park ( with a bit of nudging from a
patrolman ) at about 9:17 PM.

In closing:
 Despite moments of physical misery , I had a great time! It was
so good to see so many happy faces again. We were joined together
by the music and friendship and our defiance of and merging with 
the wind and the rain. Many thanks to Ethan Miller and John Carel
for exposing their speakers and electrical equipment to the hostile
elements. I'm assuming Joe Rice provided the ambient site sound
equipment - thank you Joe! Hello again and au revoir to everyone
who I met ( I was the guy with a gray turtleneck shirt and black and
yellow checked "Goofy" (tm) shirt and clunky red "SFR" cap . Next
time - better outdoor clothes!). God bless everybody who was there.

Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Jamie :)

A Sense of Freedom our only Sight

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Feb 25 22:56:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA07297; Sun, 25 Feb 1996 22:56:08 -0800
Received: from ix12.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA07290; Sun, 25 Feb 1996 22:56:06 -0800
Received: from  by ix12.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id WAA24437; Sun, 25 Feb 1996 22:55:31 -0800
Date: Sun, 25 Feb 1996 22:55:31 -0800
Message-Id: <199602260655.WAA24437@ix12.ix.netcom.com>
From: shawna-@ix.netcom.com (Shawna McGourty)
Subject: FnF review
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I showed up at FnF about 3pm or so, it was a cool set up.  It 
was in this outdoors area at Pt. Richmond, I've never been there 
before.  When I first got there, there weren't that many people there, 
and I was kinda lacking in energy.  Then I remembered that I forgot to 
have my coffee that day, so after hanging out for a while by myself 
staring out to sea (it was right on the beach), I hopped back into my 
car & went out in search of a big ol' cup of coffee.  After attaining 
said coffee, I later returned back to FnF, and there were suddenly a 
huge bunch of people there!  The music rocked, lotsa people were 
dancing, & it was a lot of fun.  At that point the weather was pretty 
nice, and it was one of those days where, even tho it was daylight, the 
moon was still riding high in the sky!  Later in the day, the clouds 
came back and it began raining some.  It wasn't that bad, no enormous 
downpours or anything, but it was enough to drive off some of the 
people that were there before, which left just us dancers dancing 
around in the rain & mud.  It's cool to dance in the rain!  And later 
on, as sunset began, miraculously the clouds began to disperse and the 
rain stopped, and there again was the moon shining brightly in the dark 
blue sky with venus blazing away near it.  Right across the water was 
the Richmond bridge (our park was right near the entrance to that 
bridge), and at dusk they turned the lights on.  So we now have the 
crescent moon, Venus, the sunset, the bridge all lit up, the ocean, and 
the whole group of friends & family madly dancing the dusk away!  You 
couldn't get the smile off my face!  A lot of us stayed till the bitter 
end, when it was completely dark and we were freezing our asses off, & 
we danced just as much to stay warm as for the sake of dancing.  Then 
they broke down all the equipment, & several of us lounged around 
talking with friends.  All in all, it was a blast!

Love,
Shawna

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 26 09:16:38 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA07181; Mon, 26 Feb 1996 09:16:38 -0800

Received: by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA24005; Mon, 26 Feb 96 09:15:49 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9602261715.AA24005@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: F&F!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 26 Feb 96 9:15:48 PST
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

F&F was a blast.  It was a too cold by the chill out area so I ended
up spending the entire time dancing on the dirt/mud by the main system.
Good decision not to have this party at the Berkely Marina where we 
would have killed a lot of grass.

Scott (Cloud Factory) started things of with a great variety ofi upbeat
tunes that quickly warmed things up.  His set seemd to coax the sun
into thinking "hey, I want in on this!" and out it came to join us for a
bit.  Tim (I think) followed and soon started playing some really fresh-
sounding stuff.  I'm not totally up on the latest categorizations; 
Electro?  IDM?  Lot's of cool backward sound effects and the most 
inventive non-jungle rhythm programming i've heard in ages - complex,
weird, but always maintaining the groove.  I went nuts.  I remember
thinking once "Hey tim, can you please play something boring so I can
go take a leak?"  

Besides the exciting music and (to my ears) flawless mixing, the sound
quality was superb.  Special thanks to Ethan, John Carel, Joe Rice and
everyone else who contributed equipment and helped haul it out.  You
guys really care and a lot of us really appreciate it.  This isn't guitar 
noise we're listening to;  The music we love covers the entire sound 
spectrum and so much of it gets lost when a system can't deliver. 

Next up was, uh, "Wild Jeff" (?).  Who is this kid?  He seemed to have 
a little bit of that "I'm a superstar" attitude (perhaps just my
imagination) but his set was incredible.  A mix of acid, progressive
house, techno, trance; it all sounded new, positive, and flowed
together.  I can sum it up in one word: Wow.  

I became a wimp at around 6:30, after 4 hours of nonstop bliss.
It was nice seeing all the familiar faces (Hey Geoff, we missed you).
With all that great music, outdoors with nature, I couldn't have 
asked for anything more.  Thanks again! 

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 26 09:41:15 1996

Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id JAA10242; Mon, 26 Feb 1996 09:41:11 -0800

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Mon, 26 Feb 1996 09:40:08 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tony@xinet.COM (Tony Rotundo)
Subject: Friends and Family -- an early morning review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

For those that decided not to come because of the inevitable rain, I'm
sorry.  I can understand, I too was hesitant and waited through my coffe to
hear the rush of a full-on down pour, but it never came.  I called the
voice mail and Ethan sounded so enthusiastic, what could one do but check
it out.

Friends and Family, February 24, 1996 -- Pt. Molate Park, California

I swear to you, the clouds parted before us.  It was as if the shield of
faith that the rain wouldn't come held tight and kept the rain off for at
least four hours.  Imagine a line of freaks along the ocean-side edge of
the park dancing the clouds away.  It did rain at around five or so, but
not too hard.  In fact it was rather nice to see Dave "Man of 1,000 lights"
erect a rain shelter faster than I could open a beer.  And then another
(shelter...:^).

"Yeah, but *those* clouds aren't going to seperate for us" I said pointing
to a black, ominous wall of thunderstaorms.  "Aw, man, those are blowing
the other way!" Replied Ethan with faith.  And they did.  I had to smile.

At it's peak, about 300 or so people came out to Pt. Molate to dance and
smile and hug.  It was a wonderful day.

Kudos to those crazy FnF kids!

Tone

P.S.  I have to say, I worte this at 2am Saturday night completely freaking
my friends out when I said, "I'm going to work to write email!"  They
thought I was nuts.  At least I was wise enough to reread it this morning.

From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: My Friends & Family Experience
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Kilgak Granitehand finally learned that Elembeth is a Spellfire
wielder, and...oh, wait!  Wrong update :)
        This was one of the most enjoyable parties I've been to yet!  I got
there a little after 4pm, and there was already a friendly vibe, and people
having fun.  I saw some familiar friends (hi Shawna, Jonathan, Rachel,
Nikki (sp?), Crunchman, et al) and that made me feel welcome, especially
since no one from "The Crew" was there.  They don't know what they missed!
I met some wonderful new friends, too (hi Sun, Starchild, Purple Tiger,
Phoenix, and the tall English fellow!).  Yes, there was a guy named Sun
there, so we had a brightly-shining sun with us the entire time!  It was
easy to get into the spirit of dancing, and being outdoors gave the scene a
tribal feel the likes of which I've found only at Grateful Dead shows, if
you can believe that!
        The rains came to cool us off and clense us, and most of us didn't
mind too much that it was so chilly.  Dancing and staying close together
helped, and enough of us projected our desire for a clear spot in the sky
to drive the rain past us that it came to pass!  I missed the tea, but the
hot chocolate was an excellent call.  This was the first outdoor party I
enjoyed, mostly because it was such a new experience being at the water's
edge, dancing in the rain, meeting more new friends than usual, as I was in
a good talking mode.  For the first time, I danced for nearly the entire
time, pausing only to chat with the legendary John the Raver Draper before
hitting the dance crowd again when it was dark.
        The last DJ (Minor Minor?) impressed me, and Rachel directed my
attention to him, and also helped me to sort out my head at the end so I
could remember that there were domestic issues awaiting my attention at
home, so I'm glad I didn't blow it by following the party crowd to the
other side of the bay, as I otherwise would have.  The party ended in good
time for me to get home, take care of things, and hit the sack, all the
while still carrying all the joy inside me that I both brought to and found
among you all.
        Super big hugs, smiles, and lots of love and THANKS to everyone who
was there, especially to those whose names I don't yet have down but with
whom I got to chat and dance.  I was glad that I didn't overdo anything,
had enough of my own water to drink and still offer to many people.

Love y'all!

- E

At 9:15 AM 2/26/96, Lee Fogel wrote:

>Next up was, uh, "Wild Jeff" (?).  Who is this kid?  He seemed to have
>a little bit of that "I'm a superstar" attitude (perhaps just my
>imagination) but his set was incredible.  A mix of acid, progressive
>house, techno, trance; it all sounded new, positive, and flowed
>together.  I can sum it up in one word: Wow.

His name is BIOJeff (actually, his name is Jeff McGann, and he's from
Sacramento).  He's been spinning for a while now (3-4 years), and is just
now becoming appreciated in The City.  But it's a long process, that jump
from spinning for your pets to spinning for 300 and more, right?

I can tell you Lee, and anyone else interested, he does not have a
"superstar" attitude.  I know him well, and I say this even if my judge of
character doesn't mean shit to you.  He's a GREAT guy.  In speaking with
him after the party, he not only appreciated the opportunity to spin for
Friends and Family, he was excited about the set and said it was amazing to
see the reaction the crowd gave him.  We talked about the magical loop that
flows from DJ to dancers to DJ.

He'll be happy to hear your thoughts...

:^)
Tony

P.S.  Now all he needs is email!

>Lee Fogel and Tony both wrote about Jeff/BIOJeff --

I gotta say this guy was SO RIGHT ON I couldn't believe it, we had just gotten
there, it was raining, and the music was SO PERFECT with that amazing happy
vibing crowd, I kept asking people who he was until I found out -- the rain, the
music, the people, the dancing, I was totally high on it ...

us, and his stuff just kept rolling into different happy can't resist music..

this was my first F&F event, and I can't wait 'til the next...

what a way to spend an afternoon, thank you everyone who put your time and
effort into making that happen for us - what a gift it was..

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: More interesting stuff
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Here is some interesting insights from Moscow and the Rave scene there.
I ran across this dude who posted in UKDance mailing list.   I've since
been in Email contact with this dude,  who is providing me with some
pretty good stuff,  and I want to share it with you.

>Re. underground raves... Hmmm, no, not so many. There're some, but
>(1) irregular, (2) in different places, (3) mostly organized for
>"tusovka" /friends/ - about < 200 people. Also Ptyuch is the only
>underground club in Moscow.

>Re. authorities. Sometimes... they always want to you to pay. If
>you pay 'em good money don't worry... use drugs, fuck on the
>street, burn the national flag, etc. Money!!!

>Re. America ("Sweet land of liberty"). I know... OK, "Sweet land
>of liberty..." is from America (My Country 'Tis of Thee) - 1831.
>"Thy liberty in LAW..." (?!) is from America, the Beautiful -
>1893(?). 1996 -??? What the HELL is LIBERTY in LAW?

>Radio... Yes, we have lots of various radio stations in Moscow.
>But the most interesting is Radio "Station" (106.8 FM), formed in
>Oct. 1995. "Station" is the first 24 hr. rave radio station in
>Russia.

>Your Web. Yeh, I did... COOL. Nice picture... nice glasses! Check
>http://www.moscow.net (Moscow Business Tel. Guide + Moscow Map) -
>just general info re. Moscow. More URLs soon...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Feb 26 14:57:46 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA17162; Mon, 26 Feb 1996 14:57:46 -0800
Received: from dons.ac.usfca.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id OAA17150; Mon, 26 Feb 1996 14:57:42 -0800
Message-Id: <199602262257.OAA17150@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: splitting the list?  What the hell?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 26 Feb 1996 14:56:05 -0800 (PST)
From: lanima00 <lanima00@dons.ac.usfca.EDU>
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1618
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i hope that the idea to split the list into separate lists was a joke.  if it
wasn't, here's my $.02

if that idea was a joke and i haven't figured it out yet, read no further,
for it shall embarass me.  but if it is a real idea, that my opinions follow.

NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  NO!  

i got drawn into this list because it was a community.  it dealt with
partys, spirituality, music, drugs, helping each other, meeting
cool people, and many other things.  i lumped them all into the word "raving",
and i think that many others have, also.  once these things are separated, we
are no longer a community.  at that point, we're just a bunch of
single issue listserves like brewing beer, programming perl, etc. 
we are much more than that, and i would be very dissapointed to see
that go away.  in fact, i would possibly be a little angry. possibly i value
this community more than others, but it makes my life just a little bit
fuller and more fun.  the uniqueness of sfraves is that we deal with so
many things and, in fact, function like a community.  we deal with the
shit that communities deal with, like flame wars.  we deal with the great
stuff that communities deal with, like making friends and dancing
together.  what other listserv would invite its members to the owner's
wedding party?

i think i have spoken.  i hope that was a joke.  call me ultra-sensitive
and touchy, but the thought of it splitting almost made me sick.

peace, love, and sfraves-

matt l.

p.s. any responses to this, please respond to me personally because i'm
not getting my posts for some reason.

mdpkl

On Mon, 26 Feb 1996 MEAD@uwplatt.edu wrote:

> 
> oh yeah, i'm staying with friends in Pleasanton. anyone live near there?
> and do any of you have a cafe or coffee shop you regularly hang out at?

Although not a sfraves hang out, you should check out Yo' Mama's Cafe on 
College Ave.  On Saturday from 5-9 there are two cool Jungle DJ's who spin: 
Stareyes and Thad.  On other nights various dj's spin anything from 
hip-hop to techno and house.  Check it out.  There is a good vibe, 
although it is poorly known and doesn't have a strong local following.  
But, it SHOULD, 'cuz it's a nice place to hang out.  (I don't know the 
address.  YOu can get it from the calendar.  It's at the end of College 
Ave, where it intersects Broadway---in Oakland).

--kc

Well this was one mental weekend!!! I went to FnF from about 5 til it 
finished, met Eric Pedersen, and generally had a wild time. The sprinkles 
didnt bother me at all, I really enjoyed Minor Minor's set at the end. 
After the music stopped we went back to Crunchman's house, ate, then 
headed for Techno Temple. We got there a little after 11 and even though 
the $20 seemed high we headed in. Met Jondabomb outside  Hi He is totally 
right. It was the complete BOMB. I spent the whole night in the trance 
room. I don't know the order of the dj's except that Sausee ended with a 
set that was SICK SICK SICK. (I think some of the record skipping was my 
fault Sorry) it was totally worth $20. If any of you are in direct 
contact with those who put this on give them my total thanks for  a night 
of complete brilliance. (BTW like Jon I wasn't on anything all night 
except the irresistable force of the music compelling me to move, on and 
on and on. Thanks again.

I know this has been asked before, but I go to raves often and am concerned
about my hearing.  What type of earplugs are there out on the market?  Ask
far as being as unnoticable as possible, yet safe.  I still want to be able
to hear the music as well.  I heard that there is a type that filters out
the bad noise but the rest can be heard quite clearly, is this true?  Also I
heard that only high end noise damages the ear, is this true or can bass
also damage ears?  Responses are well appreciated!  

                                           Peace,  Matt

the same email location.

i call it "spammer"

 Matt-this has become fast concern for me too.... I've found that the generic
store bought kind that are yellow and spongy do the trick:). I've used 
these for the past 3 months and have had no problems,ex.-ringing in my ears-
after I went home... Your hearing is a precious thing- don't fuck with it 
people!

I just hadda get my 2 centz in....

I spent most of the afternoon over at the ambient jungle gym at friends 
and family.  Yes, I am an ambient fiend!!!

Andrew started out and was great.  Then Ronan went on and completely blew 
my mind.  Ronan, you were right on yesterday!  Then Fred mellowed me out 
even further with some reggae inspired dub.  And then Clair got spacey 
and beautiful with mind-altering music.  Yes, it was cold, yes it rained, 
but it just made the mood more perfect.  Tod, Sarah, Philip and I danced 
and huddle under blankets all afternoon, and then trucked over to Gaby 
and Billy's for a wonderful evening listening to music and hanging out.  

It was the first time I'd heard Clair play.  She gets my vote for playing 
at the next party.

I just hope the tapes come out okay!  Because I wanna listen to it again 
and again.

And many thanks to Joe, for not tearing down the system even when the 
wind and rain picked up.  And for bringing the system in the first place 
and to Monty and everyone else who helped set up.

Seeyou soon,

Ann

Matt Wietzke wrote:
> 
> I know this has been asked before, but I go to raves often and am concerned
> about my hearing.  What type of earplugs are there out on the market?  Ask
> far as being as unnoticable as possible, yet safe.  I still want to be able
> to hear the music as well.  I heard that there is a type that filters out
> the bad noise but the rest can be heard quite clearly, is this true?  Also I
> heard that only high end noise damages the ear, is this true or can bass
> also damage ears?  Responses are well appreciated!
> 
>                                            Peace,  Matt

 Well as far as Ive ever investigated...all frequencies can damage your hearing...120dB of a 
high tone will hurt...while 120dB of bas feels g.o.o.o.o.o.o.o.o.o.o.o.d :) But the fact is 
they're both super loud sounds.
 Here in Canada if you work in a place that you need these, workers comp pays for them 
(such as in a nightclub), or they pay for half or something.
 A docotr pours this warm wax stuff in your ear..he gets a shape of the inside of your ear, 
then makes a very small clear hearing aid shaped plug. Supposedly you could be infront of a 
nice stack of speakers and the person next to you wouldnt even have to raise their voice for 
you to hear them. Now how true it rrrrrrrrrreally is I dont know...everybodies hearing is 
different...my friends absolutley swear by them.
 Here they're around $100.
 So, look around..go to your doctor and ask :)

Hi everyone!

Over the past 6 months or so I've made a number of new sections and changes
to the SFRaves web site that never got officially announced or anything,
so if you haven't seen it, or haven't gone to it for a long time, here's
a list of what's there now.  Suggestions for new sections or other info
is welcome, although I may not be able to work on some things right away.
If anyone wants to work on a section, we may be able to arrange for access to
the web server.

The home page has links to all of the major sections, a link to a 
"shocked" page, and links to local rave-related web sites (Ameba,
Frequency-8, Wicked, etc) and links to a few other areas' rave pages.

Yellow pages: a list of phone numbers to parties, clubs, rave-related
        businesses and hotlines.
White pages: a compilation of the "biographies" posted by members several
        months ago (compiled by John Darrow).
Archives: copies of all messages posted to SFRaves in its history
History: a short summary of the history of SFR
Flyers: a directory of scanned flyer images
Photos: a directory of images of people and parties 
Map: A map of central SF with markers for key stores and clubs - good for
        visitors...
Demos: Currently just one file, a demo of my interactive turntable setup
Documents: a directory of a few 'administrative' files

and of course, the latest version of the SFR calendar.


-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On Mon, 26 Feb 1996, Matt Wietzke wrote:

> I know this has been asked before, but I go to raves often and am concerned
> about my hearing.  What type of earplugs are there out on the market?

There are two types I know of, that insert in the ear (most unnoticable). 
Those are disposable (bad enviromentally) and non-disposable. You can 
hear the music fine with either. Toilet paper, wadded into a little ball 
works well also.

  Ask
> far as being as unnoticable as possible, yet safe.  I still want to be able
> to hear the music as well.  I heard that there is a type that filters out
> the bad noise but the rest can be heard quite clearly, is this true?  Also I
> heard that only high end noise damages the ear, is this true or can bass
> also damage ears?

Any frequency can damage the hearing mechanism if too loud for too long.


  Responses are well appreciated!  
> 
>                                            Peace,  Matt
> 
> 
> 

Here is the scoop-- There are two types of sound that damage hearing.. 
loud, percussive sounds that happen suddenly with no warning (gunshots 
etc.) and sustained, loud sounds. What happens is that your ear canal 
thickens when exposed to loud sounds in order to protect itself. Sudden 
loud sounds do not allow the canal enough time to adjust. Long durations 
cause the muscles to tire so that they cannot filter the loud sound well. 
Also, the little hairs in the choclea (please forgive my spelling) that 
bend in response to sound and stimulate the nerves that tell your brain 
that you are hearing that particular frequency (different hairs for 
different frequencys) will break with use and age-- broken hairs do not 
respond to stimuli (sound). This is why you can have partial hearing loss 
at certain frequencys but not others. Protect your hearing!!!!

Personal walkman type cassette decks and CD players (earplug type) are 
probably the worst thing for your hearing. Turning up your car stereo to 
cover traffic noise is not good either--especially if done on a daily 
basis (commuters are you listening?) and/or in a very noisy car.
                                      (peace out)
                                        /
                                   =*= /
                                    ~ 
                               Ran

But only if you are working from an 8 track master recording...
If you are trying, let's say, to take the lead vocal out of a tape of 
Street Fighting Man by the Rolling Stones that you dubbed off your CD, 
this plan won't work.  However, if you are lucky enough to have an 
8-track master (eg. guitar on track 1, bass on track 2, drum and rhythm 
on track 3, etc.) you can take out and put back in whatever you want...

$.02

Matt Wietzke wrote:
> Also I
> heard that only high end noise damages the ear, is this true or can bass
> also damage ears?  Responses are well appreciated!

Most hearing damage happens an octave to two above the frequency of the
damaging sound.

This means that mid-bass (200-500Hz) is probably the most damaging thing as
it will cause you to lose your hearing in the voice range.

Subject: Friends and Family and Techno Temple - A review
Cc: uk-dance@tqmcomms.co.uk, ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au,
        bmozgovoi@glas.apc.org

Precedence: bulk

Friends and Family and Techno Temple
A Review by Crunchman

The Friends and Family outdoor daytime party WENT OFF despite the
rain that started towards the evening.

After getting there late to Friends and Family,  an outdoor daytime
rave/get together,   we find about 150 SFRavers and friends groovin
to some pretty good trancey tunes.

After about a half hour,  it started to rain,  but we had adequate
warning as the covers were put up and adjusted to protect the
speakers from the rain.

There was no dry place to sit down,  so danced all the time,
managing to keep reasonably dry.   Keeping warm wasn't a problem,
due to the excellent music and continuously dancing.

At some point,  the music had faded down slightly,  and I hear others
say the police had arrived,  but apparently we were allowed to
continue until the park closed.    I suppose the cops probably thought
we were crazy to be dancing out in the rain,  but that's just fine with
me,  as long as I was able to dance.

After the rave ended,   we headed out for dinner and checked the
directions to "Techno-Temple".

TT was in this new venue,  a dance studio in the Mission in SF.   The
Gangsta factor was high,   and those many that knew me were happy
to see me,  gave me the "high five" and were happy to see me,  and
told me they haven't seen me in a while.   Which was probably true,
because I've been attending more of the "Underground" events,  and
I don't like giving extended reports on Underground events for
obvious reasons.

We get there about 11 PM,   and about 50 people in line to get in.
We were told it hasn't started yet,  but we could hear the music
going full bore.    Eventually we get in and learn it was $20 (Ouch!).
Score yet another point for Promoter greed.   If they had put the
admittance fee on the flyer,   nobody would show up,  but they didn't
even put the price on the info line.

As soon as we go in,  we were hit with the heat and humidity in the
place.    Already,  there were 900 people inside,  and it was packed.
Score another point for the lies I received at the door when this dude
said it hadn't started it,  and all the time,  there was 900 people at
the door.

Being dressed for cold weather,  I quickly shed my layers,  but not
fast enough to avoid being soaked to the skin in sweat and I haven't
even started dancing yet.

"Time to check this place out!",   as I say to myself,   and proceed to
walk around.   Hearing this awesome trance music coming from the
smaller (And much cooler) room,  I make a bee-line for it,  and
immediately start dancing.   Great trance!!   Didn't see very many
SFRavers in there,  but Brian would have really dug the trance,  but
didn't see him there.   Excellent music,  ALL NEW,  and fresh cuts I
haven't heard before.   Getting DJ information was tough,   nobody
standing by the turn tables know who he was,  and I didn't want to
bother the DJ because he was so focused on his set.

It didn't take me long to be totally wet,  so it didn't take me long to
discover the fan,   and worked my way over to it.

Eventually,  I left the trance room and started exploring.   Through
another door,  I find the "Chill room" and amazingly enough,  the chill
room was cool (They had a window open to the outside world).  I
found a place to stretch and do some yoga,  before heading out
through yet another door to the main room and learn that this DJ
from the UK was spinning some good house.

The main room was stifling hot,  and could only dance in there about
15 minutes before getting totally drenched.   Even a fan offered little
relief,  provided you could even get near the fan.   Over to one side
was a really cool rap circle and some amazing agility was
displayed as some people were twirling on their heads.   One of my
Gangsta type friends asked me to join,  but I politely declined and
headed out for the cooler air.    By that time,  I had made full circle
and started to look for the men's room.   Yet another score for the
thoughtless promoters,  as I discovered this huge long line for just
ONE shitter and ONE urinal (YUKK!!)...  Now I know why a lot of the
SFRavers had avoided this rave.    Sheesh!!   Someone should have
told me....

I hang out in the entrance area for a while as it was the ONLY place
where the temperature was BELOW 100 degrees.

At some point,  the music in the main room stopped.   I hear some
spacey narration,  and I go in to see what was going on.   Just as I get
there,  I hear this much faster music starting up.   WOW!!  Real
Techno,  and the FAST KIND...   I mean,  it wasn't any 160+ BPM stuff,
but it was certainly faster than house.    I estimate 145+.

Wow!!  The music in the main room was faster than the trance
playing in the other smaller room.    I eventually head back through
the chill area to hear some amazing Jungle playing in the chill room.
WOW!!!  Really good and much faster jungle.   In the trance room,
things were getting INSANE...   It had filled up with more people,
and was getting off big time.    A different DJ was spinning,   but I
didn't care to go find out who he was,   I was entranced with the
music.   My friends were going ballistic,  bouncing off the walls.

I don't know how long I was in there dancing,   but eventually I
stopped and headed back to the main room to find that the BPM's
had picked up even more,  but minus the rap circles,  and not as
many people.   But being in San Francisco,  land of the low BPM's I
often call it,  this faster paced music is not very common.   Many of
my friends were all commenting,  saying "This music was much
faster than I like".   Me,  I just grinned and said "Yea!!  gimme more"

At about 5 AM,  the Trance room was FULL ON with good Goa trance,
somewhat harder than what Goa Gill plays.   By then,  the main room
slowed down to House again,   but the number of people were much
less,  but still no relief from the heat and humidity.   Shortly around
6 am (2 hours before the advertised ending time),   he music
stopped.    So we gathered our stuff and left.   My score...  in the
usual 1-10 scale

Venue = 3 (poorly ventilated,  no ins-and-outs,  inadequate toilet
facilities, and the list goes on)

Music = 8 (Excellent variety,  international DJs)

Sound = 7 in trance room,  6 for main room,  but sound went out a
few times.

Chill = 6 (they had their windows opened to the outside world)

Toilet = 2 ( see text above)

Visuals = 5 (Average)

	I just wanted to post a quick note especially thanking John (I 
didn't get your last name) for bringing the hot chocolate and tea for 
everyone on Saturday!  My friends & I really appreciated...
	Just getting over a cold, I was really pondering my wisdom at 
being out on chilly, windy, wet Point Molinas Saturday, and having a nice 
hot beverage there was a big plus!		
	Overall, I would have to say the party lacked the energy of past 
Friends & Family events, but considering the time (day), the weather 
(rotten) and the cost (free), I'm not complaining.  I do wish that 
someone had pointed out the ambient area to my friends & I.  It was 
mentioned on the voicemail, but when we got to the site I more or less 
assumed it wasn't happening.  You guys hid it too well!  It probably 
doesn't help that we got there when it was getting dark.  Too bad though, 
because it was my friend Liz's first rave, and she indicated that 
she would've liked some auditory relief from the throbbing techno of the 
main area.
	Anyway, phat hugzzz to all who came & made it possible. (Did I 
just spell "fat" with a "ph"??)     8)-

Much Love,

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> i'm not sure if anyone has helped you with your ?. So i'll give it a shot!! i
> know that if you have an 8 track digital recorder, like at school or
> something you can get whatever single track you want from any song.

This will only work if you've got the original 8 track digital source
media used by the performers prior to mastering. And they happen to be
using the same 8 track digital recorder you have, etc. (Good luck
getting the masters unless the musicians are your friends or your a
bang-up big-name producer that knows how to swing deals w/ record cos.)

To answer the question originally asked (as i remember it), no it's
very hard to separate a LP/CD-source of music back into the separate
tracks. I've seen ads in music mags for electronic gizmos that remove
vocals from tracks (e.g. for karaoke) but I doubt they work very well.
Probably nothing more than a "notch" filter that removes the voice
spectra and leaves just the low bass and high highs... leaving your
ears to reconstruct the original sound while your brain fools you into
thinking there isn't a gaping hole in the frequency specrum.

Why don't you just play the needed tracks yourself or hire musicians to
do the job. Musicians need employment you know...

>BEGIN QUOTE FROM Marco A. Mancia:
>>
>>Please tell me Juan did not play at MAD last
>>night..............please,...............PLEASE...................

>Next week...don't worry...

Yeah, but Phred was there and he put on a really good set ending off with a 
cut from "Havana Condensed".  He felt the mix was sloppy, but I still 
commended him on his choice of cuts.  

That was my first time to MAD.  Not what I expected, really, but then it 
*is* in the Bahia.  Small, but not claustrophic, ok lights, nice visuals, 
really good music and a surprisingly good vibe.  I mean, I had a grin on my 
face the whole time.

Got to meet the one, the only, Brian Darkness (trumpets) at MAD.  He 
graciously gave myself and a friend a gift for which I shall have to repay 
him in the very near future.  (big ole grins...)

He's only the second person I've seen from this list -- good thing he had 
his laminate!!  This time I decided I was going to have a meaningful chat, 
and I ended up dragging him outside to talk to him.  Very cool guy!

I also had a chance to prevent a little violence.  This happened on the way 
to the Bahia.  I saw a guy getting picked on by a larger, intoxicated man.  
I told my friend to pull over quick.  I jumped out, told my friend to circle 
the block and come back to pick me up.  I ran back, pretended like the guy 
getting swung at was a friend, "Hey man, been waiting long?!"  Big disarming 
grin, grabbed him by the sleeve and pulled him away, started walking down 
the street.  The big guy, almost coherent, kept yelling and was following 
us.  I made like I had understood part of what he was gibbering about, and 
laughed like it was really funny, "Is that right!  Yeah, I bet!  Ok, well, 
see ya later, pal!" and kept on walking away.  This, along with that big ole 
grin, confused the big guy enough that he decided that two guys, one of 
which wasn't that small, were too much of a headache, and he walked away.  
The guy I was walking with thanked me profusely and about a block further 
down, plenty of distance, we shook hands and parted ways.  Why am I 
including this?  Because sometimes to preserve PLUR (if I may be so bold as 
to apply it in this fashion), we have to step up and act when something bad 
is happening.  And sometimes all that's required is standing up and being 
counted, participating in even a small way to the solution.  I've never been 
good at "staying out of it".  "Getting into it" is an affirmation of life 
and humanity for me, an opportunity to help and to put smiles back on 
people's faces.

Toodles,

S

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 12:46:45 -0800 (PST)
In-Reply-To: <199602271749.JAA08551@netcom5.netcom.com> from "Niels P. Mayer" at Feb 27, 96 09:49:51 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1606      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> To answer the question originally asked (as i remember it), no it's
> very hard to separate a LP/CD-source of music back into the separate
> tracks. I've seen ads in music mags for electronic gizmos that remove
> vocals from tracks (e.g. for karaoke) but I doubt they work very well.
> Probably nothing more than a "notch" filter that removes the voice
> spectra and leaves just the low bass and high highs... leaving your
> ears to reconstruct the original sound while your brain fools you into
> thinking there isn't a gaping hole in the frequency specrum.
> 
It is very hard to do, although you can get close if you use a
program like Sound Designer.  Those gizmos in the magazines take
the left channel and invert the waveform of the right channel and
mix those together to cancel everything that was panned dead center
in the music.  The reason: In mixdowns it is typical to keep the
vocals dead center and pan the different instruments slightly left and
right for spatial effect.  So cancelling out the center removes the vocal
(and a kickdrum or two) and leaves the basslines and whatever else might
be there (echo and effects).  This can be done with a digital audio
editor, just invert one of the channels and mix them together.

although to start, you should look for sections of the song that
have the beat and bassline and cut and paste those bars over sections
where the voice is.  You can often get pretty close doing this, although
you're bound to have a few parts that sound just off... oh well...

the only other option is making the music yourself from scratch.

good luck-

-john.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Feb 27 13:01:33 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA25930; Tue, 27 Feb 1996 13:01:33 -0800

Received: from unknown (crl13.crl.com) by mail.crl.com with SMTP id AA26836

From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)

Date: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 20:58:02 GMT
Message-Id: <31336eec.155136419@mail.crl.com>
References: <199602271749.JAA08551@netcom5.netcom.com>
In-Reply-To: <199602271749.JAA08551@netcom5.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99d/32.182
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I think the way those "vocal removers" work is that they are based on
the prinicple that vocals are usually recorded to both stereo
channels, and the backing instruments tend to be more on the left
channel or the right channel.  By subtracting the output coming from
both channels simultaneously, and leaving the left or right channel
only output, one can decrease sounds recorded in the center.  I don't
know how this works in practice.

David

SDream wrote his story about helping out a stranger on the street who was
getting bulllied, and said ..... "Because sometimes to preserve PLUR (if I may
be so bold as to apply it in this fashion), we have to step up and act when
something bad is happening.  And sometimes all that's required is standing up
and being counted, participating in even a small way to the solution. 

To which I say...  RIGHT ON -- there are so many ways we can insert our positive
selves into negative situations creatively and nonthreateningly -- if he'd
jumped in and been aggressive or judgmental, things could have turned worse, but
being positive and just shifting the events and energy can totally make a
difference -- 

I was at a party in Seattle a couple of weeks ago and there was this guy who was
way gone (he later stripped naked and wandered around, that's how far gone he
was) and he decided he loved this girl there and just kept getting closer and
closer, staring at her, and though she was trying to be nice, it was scary -- so
I just stepped in and put my arms around her, giving her a big hug and asking if
she wanted my help, which she did -- and was able to divert him from her long
enough for her to make an easy exit --  not as potentially scary as SDream's
situation, but it still could have gone a different direction --

Thanks, and I hope you or someone like you is comin' along when I need a little
positive diversion to take me out of a negative!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Feb 27 15:45:35 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id PAA14365; Tue, 27 Feb 1996 15:45:35 -0800
Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA14353; Tue, 27 Feb 1996 15:45:30 -0800
Received: from [153.36.85.85] (Cust21.Max6.Santa-Clara.CA.MS.UU.NET [153.36.85.85]) by mh1.well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) with SMTP id PAA21242 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 27 Feb 1996 15:45:10 -0800
Message-Id: <199602272345.PAA21242@mh1.well.com>
X-Sender: crunch@mail.well.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 27 Feb 1996 15:45:37 +1000
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Radio stations and formats
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

They all SUCK BIG TIME,  here in the Bay Area.   How can be reverse this
dispicable distinction of being one of very few radio station markets that
DON'T have a 24 hour/7 days Techno,  House,  AMbient,  Acid Jazz format?

Large commercial radio stations only fucus on "Established" formats that
sell products,  but Live 105 has (or had) the Masters Mix every evening at
9 pm,  but when I tune in,   I sure don't get techno.   I guess it's not
on every day.   Of course KZSU has these House Marathons every so often,
but their signal coverage is small.

Is there any way that we,  as a group of people,  who are interested in
hearing (and supporting) techno on the radio.    Free Radio is ONE solution,
but won't be effective in ALL areas,  and then,  there is the FCC to contend
with.

Other solutions,   might be to approach commercial radio stations and talk to
their station managers and program directors to see if they could try the
format out for a set period of time.   Remember,  All radio stations want
to do,  is to sell Commercial time,  IE:  to make money.

I propose the following,  and would like to volunteer my knowledge of radio
station anatomy to the SFRave community in the hopes that it might actually
result in hearing a good DJ do a weekly show for 3 hour sets or even one
every day.

First step is to convence the station mananger that Techno/House music
is popular.   A good approach would be to make an appointment with the
dude,  perhaps over lunch,  down in the Haight.   Take him (the station
manager) into Ameba,  Frequency-8,  and other rave related stores,  and
ask him to count how many vehicles are blaring out Techno and House toons.

Perhaps Ameba or Frequency-8,   or a host of other rave proprieters would
be willing to pay for commercial time to "Sponsor" such a program.   Radio
station money mongers eat this shit up BIG TIME!!.

You just have to convince the station manager that Rave music SELLS COMMERCIALS
and I'm certain that Martin O Brian,  Wicked,  and other promoters would
like to have their events promoted on these shows.

I used to work in radio in another lifetime,  from programming to engineering,
and am familiar with the anatomy of such.   I also used to be a DJ on KKUP
Cupertino,  back in 1970.

As to which radio station to approach,  I would try for stations that already
play techno like Live 105,   or the hip hop station at the top of the dial,
whatever that is...

Lets see what we can do...

Crunchman

FROM: Robert Brown

SUBJECT: Radio stations and formats

  Another station that plays house/techno is KSJS, 90.5 FM.
  It's played on some mornings (somewhat random mornings it seems -
  but usually when Tyler is the dj - she's rather cool).
  Their number is (408) 924 KSJS I believe.  That's the DJ/request line.

  As you might be able to tell from the letters, it is SJSU's station,
  thus limited coverage area, mostly the South Bay.

Mime-Version: 1.0

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: Radio stations and formats
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>They all SUCK BIG TIME,  here in the Bay Area.   How can be reverse this
>dispicable distinction of being one of very few radio station markets that
>DON'T have a 24 hour/7 days Techno,  House,  AMbient,  Acid Jazz format?
>
>Large commercial radio stations only fucus on "Established" formats that
>sell products,  but Live 105 has (or had) the Masters Mix every evening at
>9 pm,  but when I tune in,   I sure don't get techno.   I guess it's not
>on every day.   Of course KZSU has these House Marathons every so often,
>but their signal coverage is small.
>
>Is there any way that we,  as a group of people,  who are interested in
>hearing (and supporting) techno on the radio.    Free Radio is ONE solution,
>but won't be effective in ALL areas,  and then,  there is the FCC to contend
>with.


why?

I don't see any reason to turn a community like this one into an on-the-air
fully sponsored business extravaganza.

If there were a radio station devoted to techno, we'd be in the same
situation as Europe-- techno is huge over there, and they have radio
stations devoted to the format, and the result is that raving has become a
big business instead of a community like I believe it should be (that's
just my opinion though)...

I can't even begin to count how many tight undergraound music genres have
been ruined by overexposure on commercial radio and mTV and the like... In
a few years, everyone would be complaining about how techno used to be cool
before it sold out, and every rave would be attended by massive amounts of
twits who have no idea what the community atmosphere's about, they just
want to get down, get doped up, and get laid. Look waht happened to
Berkeley's punk scene when Green Day hit it big... they scene was exploited
by radio and record companies and Mtv who were searching for another image
to sell to the masses of uncreative teens begging for a prepackaged image
to buy.

Commercial rave radio would be sooo bad IMHO. If everyone could just flip
on KRAV whenever they wanted to, what would be the incentive to seek out
the real underground parties?

my $.02
-mike.

On Tue, 27 Feb 1996, michal migurski wrote:

> If there were a radio station devoted to techno, we'd be in the same
> situation as Europe-- techno is huge over there, and they have radio
> stations devoted to the format, and the result is that raving has become a
> big business instead of a community like I believe it should be (that's
> just my opinion though)...

	Underground parties have always been around and they always will
be. I have been to some really good parties in the UK yet techno is nearly
as mainstream as blur. There was a term for the dodgy folks who were into
techno but looked the look and sported the hard attitude cuz they were
everywhere. And you look around here, its a community to a certain degree
but we don't have the likes of what the travellers in Europe do or the
roaming party that goes up and down the coast of India is rumored to have.
	Is the "community" that has come out of rave based on the music or the
people within the community? And why does the music have to stay hidden
(well, besides the fact that that one special track will most likely get
played every half hour til you want to stomp your radio to bits if its a
commerical station). If you are worried about the community breaking up, I
doubt that would happen but it might move a bit.

dave

As a DJ on KDVS, the UC Davis campus radio station, I would like to give 
a big up to John for his comments.  KDVS is primarily (right or wrong) a 
punk/indie rock station.  However, there was a big push a while back and 
the hip-hop folks made their claim on a few slots during the programming 
cycle.  Nowadays, myself and acouple of others have been trying to get 
techno/house/rave/whathaveyou into the more respected spots (eg. not 3am, 
eternal or not, nobody listens at 3 on wednesday...).  The biggest thing 
that would help out a show like mine on KDVS (I will be back on the air 
starting next quarter) would be sponsorships!  Since KDVS is a 
non-commercial station, you wouldn't get "commercials" per se, but you 
would get mentions for having sponsored the show.  I am not trying to 
plug for sponsors, but I am trying to impart my knowledge of how our 
station works...
I have done sub. shows for other DJ's during non-vampyre hours and had 
bunches of callers really excited asking if KDVS is going to be playing 
house/techno at htis time on a regular basis and I have to tell them no, 
you have to tune in between three and seven am if you want to hear this 
stuff here.  I _know_ that there would be a big listener base in KDVS's 
broadcast range for a reasonable hour techno program.  The problem is 
convincing the program director (who really really really dilikes techno) 
that he should take the risk and put me on.
Anyway....

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---

                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor

> big business instead of a community like I believe it should be (that's

> I can't even begin to count how many tight undergraound music genres have
> been ruined by overexposure on commercial radio and mTV and the like... In
> a few years, everyone would be complaining about how techno used to be cool
> before it sold out, and every rave would be attended by massive amounts of
> twits who have no idea what the community atmosphere's about, they just
> want to get down, get doped up, and get laid. Look waht happened to
> Berkeley's punk scene when Green Day hit it big... they scene was exploited
> by radio and record companies and Mtv who were searching for another image
> to sell to the masses of uncreative teens begging for a prepackaged image
> to buy.
> 
> Commercial rave radio would be sooo bad IMHO. If everyone could just flip
> on KRAV whenever they wanted to, what would be the incentive to seek out
> the real underground parties?
> 
> my $.02
> -mike.

	well said, mike.
	i love our scene the way it is, underground.
perhaps in our evolutionary paths raving will contribute to mass feelings 
of communtiy among so many varied ethnic groups, peoples, ideas, ... but 
i wouldnt count on community being perpetuated thru the media, ...
love comes from love, community grows from community, - i dont think that 
peace can be made to be a fad or fasion, the thing to do to be cool... 
because fasion fades, whereas teh real thing is inside our hearts, forever!
	i love our scene!
	i will support its growth, bring people into it individually, out 
of love.... and when our scene becomes huge, it will be the real thing:)

	thats MHO. 
evoluton of energy:)

The next best thing to radio, I've discovered through my stays at Wayne's, is
Digital Music Express.  It is nonstop music with no commercials and they 
have a dance music station and one that is more ambient, but leans on the 
New Age side.  The dance music station is actually pretty decent!  It is 
really good if you want music in your house all day with no 
interruptions, and the remote control that comes with it shows the 
artist, title and the name of the record/CD or whatever.  I know I want 
it when I move to the city. 

love,
Amy

> 	well said, mike.
> 	i love our scene the way it is, underground.
> perhaps in our evolutionary paths raving will contribute to mass feelings 
> of communtiy among so many varied ethnic groups, peoples, ideas, ... but 
> i wouldnt count on community being perpetuated thru the media, ...
> love comes from love, community grows from community, - i dont think that 
> peace can be made to be a fad or fasion, the thing to do to be cool... 
> because fasion fades, whereas teh real thing is inside our hearts, forever!

There are a lot of aging hippies(and some new ones) that would agree with 
you. They endure, and I respect them for that. However, they had to deal 
with the mass commercialization of their scene and wait for the 'fad' to 
pass. 

Any scene can and will be commercialized once enough people realize that 
they can make a buck off of it. It happened to the hippies, it happened 
to the 'alternative' scenes, and to a lesser degree the punk and gothic 
scenes. It is to a small degree commercialized in the U.S. which will 
most likely increase with the influence from Europe, and when more people 
realize that they can make a dollar off of the 'scene.' 

Endure. What you will be left with is all the wonderful people that 
mattered in the first place.

                                              Black Adder

On Feb 27,  5:30pm, 'Dave Bayer' wrote:
> Subject: Re: Radio stations and formats
>
>
> On Tue, 27 Feb 1996, michal migurski wrote:
>
> > If there were a radio station devoted to techno, we'd be in the same
> > situation as Europe-- techno is huge over there, and they have radio
> > stations devoted to the format, and the result is that raving has become a
> > big business instead of a community like I believe it should be (that's
> > just my opinion though)...

[snip]
> 	Is the "community" that has come out of rave based on the music or the
> people within the community? And why does the music have to stay hidden
> (well, besides the fact that that one special track will most likely get
> played every half hour til you want to stomp your radio to bits if its a
> commerical station). If you are worried about the community breaking up, I
> doubt that would happen but it might move a bit.

You may change your mind when the parties you are used to go to are swamped
by idiots who do not understand what the vibe or the community is about
but basically go there because it is the in thing to do. I saw this happen
in The Netherlands were the rave scene became huge within a few years. Even
though underground parties still exist, I would say it is difficult to find
one with the same quality of people as I used to meet in, say, 1990.
And I have seen reports of raves on this mailing lists complaining about
the gangsta/prep boy/macho percentage of the audience of certain events.
Apparently these people already know where to be and how to act (not).
The same is happening to the Internet in a sence. Nowadays every idiot (no
offense meant to those who did) get a AOL account and still only a small
percentage of the people in the world is hooked up. I still prefer quality
over quantity but that's just my $0.02...

Later,

The Frying Dutchman

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 01:31:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id BAA02176; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 01:31:36 -0800
Received: from well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA02169; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 01:31:34 -0800
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id BAA11161 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 01:31:39 -0800
Date: Wed, 28 Feb 1996 01:31:39 -0800
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.com>
Message-Id: <199602280931.BAA11161@well.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: what i did on my winter vacation
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mostly, worked.  But arriving in SF Friday night after another punishing
week of bad weather in Portland, I was hoping for some relief, and more
or less got it, though it is unseasonably cool in SF as well.

Friday night I checked out the Top, where the Hardkisses sponsor a weekly.
DJs were Graeme and Charlotte, and as usual I had a good time.  The old
house crew, those who still go out anyway, seem to be drifting towards
these kinds of gatherings these days . . .

Saturday was F&F . . . with any better weather luck, it would have been
wonderful, but merely really good will have to suffice I guess!  Over
at the ambient stage (a converted kids jungle gym at the park), each
DJ got different weather: Andrew got Clouds, Ronan got Sunshine, I got
Storm, and Claire got Moon & Stars.  Pretty weird how it changed like
that, but there you are.  Big thanks to Ann, Greg, Philip, Joe and
everyone else who battened down the hatches while I piloted the Ark
of Dub through the storm.  It got a little drippy there at the DJ
station but no big deal, and I played pretty nice dub and jungle.
Can't wait to hear the tapes!  

I liked the rest of F&F too, though I couldn't stay late because of
my ride leaving.  A good start to the outside scene for the year, and
I was very pleased to see lots of people come out for this one.  
Point Molate is an excellent location . . .

Saturday night I went to the Cafe Bastille in the Financial District in
SF for Vanilla Fudge, which is a semi-regular every-other-week-or so
house music oriented thing.  Upstairs are a bunch of very drunk French
people, and downtown is a really cool little area with tables and a
small dance floor and DJs Corey Black, Sunshine and Lee spinning old-skool
deep house.  Nice one!

oops, my bus is leaving, more l8r

phred

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 01:49:28 1996

Sorry this is kind of long, but that whole radio thing got to me!!! and I
dont mean to bitch, but this is how i feel:

I have a friend who works at one of the "alternative" radio stations here in
the bay area, she listens to all the new stuff that comes in, thats part of
her job.  anyway she was explaining to me that she talked to the music
director about getting some"techno" songs played on the air.  Music Director
is not hip to the idea.  True that good sounding music  = money, but that
good sounding music that sounds good to you and appeals to you better sound
good and appeal to the rest of the other 250,000 listners that are listening
along with you, otherwise that  = no money and poor ratings.  Thats exactly
why the Music Director at this particular station isn't hip to the idea of
techno on his station.....it won't sell, not on his station cause people are
more "rock" driven !! In Short, if the music doesn't sell to the listners
then ratings go down and less air time is bought for commercials.....so he
doesn't want to take any chances!!

and about the community of ravers that we now have...people who invest their
money and time into these parties are NOT in it for the love, or the
community !! Thats the biggest front ive ever seen, i hang out with some of
these people, do you think that they give their money away to the
"community"?! NOT !!  Have you seen the cars that these people drive??????
Theyre in there spliting and counting up the money the second the party is
over!!!  But i do believe that our community of ravers as a people, are about
love and a sense of community and all that good stuff....and yes i believe
that there are still some good people out there who actually throw parties
for the "community" and love and fun of it!!

About "techno" music becoming popular and extending to people who don't know
what raves are about.....IT HAS ALREADY HAPPENED!!!!!!  Take a look around at
the next party you go to....raves are TRENDY!!!  They havent much gotten to
the underground parties, but they will!!!

hope i didnt offend anyone, sorry if i did

peace and love

jen

Well, my friend returned from England with a CD that looks like it might 
be available here; He got it at an HMV.

It's called "Loops of Fury EP" and has "Loops of Fury", "(The Best Part 
Of) Breaking Up", "Get Up On It Like This", and "Chemical Beats (Dave 
Clarke Remix)". The cover has a speed skier with heavy motion blur. I'm 
not sure that this is the "limited edition" I had heard about, but it's 
enjoyable anyway.

John Draper wrote:
> 
> They all SUCK BIG TIME,  here in the Bay Area.   

The formats of the redio stations in the bay area represent the whole United 
States.  You cant' just say that they suck here in the bay area.. They suck 
all across the U.S.

> How can be reverse this
> dispicable distinction of being one of very few radio station markets that
> DON'T have a 24 hour/7 days Techno,  House,  AMbient,  Acid Jazz format?

Start your own radio station. 
 
> Large commercial radio stations only fucus on "Established" formats that
> sell products,  but Live 105 has (or had) the Masters Mix every evening at
> 9 pm,  but when I tune in,   I sure don't get techno.   I guess it's not
> on every day.   

I think I would throw up if I heard Live 105 play techno.  Let them play
they're cheezy, mainstream, pop house music.  It wouldn't make sense for
a pop rock station to play underground music.  Underground music is reserved
for the underground scene.

>  Remember,  All radio stations want
> to do,  is to sell Commercial time,  IE:  to make money.
> 
> I propose the following,  and would like to volunteer my knowledge of radio
> station anatomy to the SFRave community in the hopes that it might actually
> result in hearing a good DJ do a weekly show for 3 hour sets or even one
> every day.
> 
> First step is to convence the station mananger that Techno/House music
> is popular.

But how popular is it reallY?  The dance music market in America represents a
small fraction of the whole music market

>   A good approach would be to make an appointment with the
> dude,  perhaps over lunch,  down in the Haight.   Take him (the station
> manager) into Ameba,  Frequency-8,  and other rave related stores,  and
> ask him to count how many vehicles are blaring out Techno and House toons.


Modern day *commercial* radio stations determine their formats and programming
schedules based on professional market research.  Programm Directors don't
program their daily playlist based on what *they* think is popular.  In addition
to in house, or contracted market research, they readradio trade publications 
like CMJ to figure out whats hot.
 
> Perhaps Ameba or Frequency-8,   or a host of other rave proprieters would
> be willing to pay for commercial time to "Sponsor" such a program.   Radio
> station money mongers eat this shit up BIG TIME!!.

Comerial time is VERY, VERY and I repeat... VERY EXPENSIVE.

> You just have to convince the station manager that Rave music SELLS COMMERCIALS

I can appreciate your feelings about trying to push the music to another level.
But think twice about who you are trying to promote this music to.  They do not 
appreciate the music.  They don't have a passion for it.  As techno fans,
we must understand that we (americans) are a minority in the world of pop  rock
music. And thats the way it should be.  I would be so pissed if I heard a
Maurizio track right after a green day song on live 105.

The pop music arena cannot put a finger on the undergound techno|house scene because
the glitter and glamour of rock and roll is absent.  Producers are satisfied by 
remaining faceless.  A common theme of the music and culture is secrecy, which
contradicts the pop market.  

I think it would be a good idea if there was a mix show on a weekend night, but I 
disagree that we should get together and "sell out" by forcing cheezy commercial
radio stations to play the underground music that we love on a 24 hr basis.  FREE
RADIO is definately a good idea.

-Jon

michal migurski wrote:

> I don't see any reason to turn a community like this one into an on-the-air
> fully sponsored business extravaganza.

AMEN!

> If there were a radio station devoted to techno, we'd be in the same
> situation as Europe-- techno is huge over there, and they have radio
> stations devoted to the format, and the result is that raving has become a
> big business instead of a community like I believe it should be (that's
> just my opinion though)...

It is inevitable that rave music will be big business.  Thats why most people
start a business.  To make money.  But we should not support the commercialism
of this culture.  NO fucking way.

> I can't even begin to count how many tight undergraound music genres have
> been ruined by overexposure on commercial radio and mTV and the like... In
> a few years, everyone would be complaining about how techno used to be cool
> before it sold out, and every rave would be attended by massive amounts of
> twits who have no idea what the community atmosphere's about, they just
> want to get down, get doped up, and get laid. Look waht happened to
> Berkeley's punk scene when Green Day hit it big... they scene was exploited
> by radio and record companies and Mtv who were searching for another image
> to sell to the masses of uncreative teens begging for a prepackaged image
> to buy.
> 
> Commercial rave radio would be sooo bad IMHO. If everyone could just flip
> on KRAV whenever they wanted to, what would be the incentive to seek out
> the real underground parties?

Or how 'bout supporting the people who give you the music.  Buy cd's, mix 
tapes, records.  Why should radio stations get big money, when talented
artists are struggling.  FORGET IT!

-Jon

'Dave Bayer' wrote:
>         Is the "community" that has come out of rave based on the music or the
> people within the community? 

That depends on where you are from.  The community that I am from is based on music.

> And why does the music have to stay hidden

Commercialism has a history of exploiting good music.  I don't think it's a bad 
thing that the music is hidden.  Look what happens when mainstream media gets into
promoting music that they know nothing about?  They push people like "Moby".  People
who have never heard the music before hear Moby, and they say:  Oh, that's techno,
that shit sucks.  Then everyone has the wrong impression of what the music really
is.  I am not against promoting the music, and introducing it to people who
aren't farmilliar, but it just has to happen in different ways.

Think about how terrible the vibe is at parties are when there are 5000 people.
Just imagine the first Live 105 Rave.  

-Jon

FREE RADIO is the only way.

------ From: John Draper, Tue, Feb 27, 1996 ------ 
>They all SUCK BIG TIME,  here in the Bay Area.   How can be reverse this
>dispicable distinction of being one of very few radio station markets that
>DON'T have a 24 hour/7 days Techno,  House,  AMbient,  Acid Jazz format?

Actually, SF area radio does *NOT* suck as John might imply. You certainly
won't find good music on commercial stations, but check out the college
stations for an incredible array of quality programming. 
For those who maybe don't read all the way down to the end of the SF Raves
calendar, I will reprint the radio listings from it:

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. [20]KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on
       [21]KUSF 90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz
       and noise [22]KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night midnight - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. [23]flux@netcom.com
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, [24]KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday morning - "The Uncle Noah TV Show" 6-9am, KDVS 90.3,
       Davis.
     * Saturday afternoon - [25]"Bustop" - music and talk w/guest DJs
       from SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. [26]KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "Saturday Night Spin Out" w/Ronnie Libido. Trip
       hop, Jungle, Ambient, Experimental Sounds. 10pm-2am. [27]KFJC 89.7
       - Los Altos Hills

I think you get a pretty good bunch of music, and a wide variety.

And, to further drive home the point, KFJC 89.7FM in Los Altos Hills will be
broadcasting the Derrik May show *in it's entirety* from 10PM - 6am this
coming Friday. It will be live using ISDN technology, and will have excellent
sound quality. Here's the lineup:
 Friday, March 1st - space children presents [3]Prometheus Unbound
 Derrick May, Stacey Pullen, Gary O, Spacetime Continuum, Jon Williams,
 Graeme, Dutch, Das. Gardening Club w/Darkhorse, Professor Smith, U.F.O, Matty
& Abstract.

I'm pretty sure we will only broadcast the main room, so you will get Derrick
May, Stacey Pullen, Gary O, Spacetime Continuum, etc. (sorry Gardening
Clubbers...) KFJC's broadcast range is very wide, from the South Bay to North
of SF. You may want to check this out if you won't be going to the show, and
want to have and amazing set of DJ's spin at your house.

Anyway, if you don't like the musical selection, join a college station, get
involved, and start playing music yourself. It's pretty easy to do, and
basically takes time and devotion to something you enjoy.

Doug



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 13:30:26 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA17194; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:30:26 -0800
Received: from ix6.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA17188; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:30:22 -0800
Received: from  by ix6.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id NAA06292; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:29:48 -0800
Date: Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:29:48 -0800
Message-Id: <199602282129.NAA06292@ix6.ix.netcom.com>
From: solle@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Solle)
Subject: Money = Bad?
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

"RADIO PLAY" and subsequent responses got me thinkin'....

In 1990 I left a regular DJ gig at Denver's Rock Island and moved back to S.F. 
where I was hired by BGP to be Bill Graham's personal producer for small events 
(mostly personal parties and fund-raisers at his residence).  Since Bill was 
friends with many of "The Dead" it was not uncommon to mingle with the likes of 
Jerry Garcia or Bob Weir.  As I'm not a Deadhead in any way, shape, or form I 
always found it a strange juxtaposition to go to a Dead show and listen to loving 
Deadheads in the parking lot talk about "f****n' capitalists" or the yuppies who 
were at that point "invading their scene for profit."  Then a week later I'd be 
at Bill Graham's mansion in the hills of Marin watching members of the Dead 
cruise up the driveway in Porsches and BMWs.

My point is this. To make the assumption that Bill Graham (promoter) or Jerry 
Garcia (player) were not in it for the love of the music or the community 
(Deadheads) would be wrong. They were lucky enough to make the passion of their 
life their business and to fill other people with happiness in the process. Pick 
an industry and the argument holds, Bill Gates (computers), Ken Grifffey Jr. 
(baseball), etc.

Making money at something isn't always bad.  Heck, in our market driven society 
money pays the rent people.  Think of all the great DJs and Promoters that we've 
lost over the years because they had to move on to something that does pay the 
rent and does have the future to pay for a child's food and education.  But I 
guess that they didn't really love the music as much.  Yeah right.

Are Deadheads and Ravers related? 
  
Just a thought...
Sunny   

   

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 13:59:48 1996

Received: from clotho.synopsys.com (clotho.synopsys.com [146.225.100.24])
  by atropos.synopsys.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with ESMTP id NAA02451; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:59:32 -0800
Received: from [146.225.72.168] (epaul-mac.synopsys.com [146.225.72.168])
  by clotho.synopsys.com (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id NAA14332; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 13:59:29 -0800
X-Sender: epaul@macpo-1
Message-Id: <v02130511ad5a7fc637cc@[146.225.72.168]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 28 Feb 1996 14:03:04 -0800
To: solle@ix.netcom.com (Christopher Solle)
From: epaul@Synopsys.COM (Eric P. Peterson)
Subject: Re: Money = Bad?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Word, bro!  I can totally relate.  Many people, including myself, would
like nothing better than to make a living at what we love to do.  For me,
that means playing music for others' enjoyment.  If I could make enough $
at it to be comfortable, I'd give most of the rest of it to causes around
the world that really do some good for people.  As it is, I make very
little through performing, and to pay bills I often do work that holds no
passion for me, and doesn't benefit others in the way I want it to.  You
hit the nail right on the head: this is a capitalist society.  Those of us
who would rather not participate in it for moral reasons have to compromise
to a certain degree (at least till the revolution occurs...).  The only
alternative I can think of is to support oneself by theft, and that's NOT
acceptable.  Money is not the root of all evil; it's the lust after money.

My two shillings :)

- E

>money pays the rent people.  Think of all the great DJs and Promoters that
>we've
>lost over the years because they had to move on to something that does pay the
>rent and does have the future to pay for a child's food and education.  But I
>guess that they didn't really love the music as much.  Yeah right.
>
>Are Deadheads and Ravers related?
>
>Just a thought...
>Sunny
>
>

Eric P. Peterson
Financial Assistant
N&CS Materials Management
Synopsys Inc.
