Dear Jen,

My computer tells me that on Wed, 28 Feb 1996 you shared:

> 
> Sorry this is kind of long, but that whole radio thing got to me!!! and I
> dont mean to bitch, but this is how i feel:
> 
> I have a friend who works at one of the "alternative" radio stations here in
> the bay area, she listens to all the new stuff that comes in, thats part of
> her job.  anyway she was explaining to me that she talked to the music
> director about getting some"techno" songs played on the air.  Music Director
> is not hip to the idea.  True that good sounding music  = money, but that
> good sounding music that sounds good to you and appeals to you better sound
> good and appeal to the rest of the other 250,000 listners that are listening
> along with you, otherwise that  = no money and poor ratings.  Thats exactly
> why the Music Director at this particular station isn't hip to the idea of
> techno on his station.....it won't sell, not on his station cause people are
> more "rock" driven !! In Short, if the music doesn't sell to the listners
> then ratings go down and less air time is bought for commercials.....so he
> doesn't want to take any chances!!
> 
> and about the community of ravers that we now have...people who invest their
> money and time into these parties are NOT in it for the love, or the
> community !! Thats the biggest front ive ever seen, i hang out with some of
> these people, do you think that they give their money away to the
> "community"?! NOT !!  Have you seen the cars that these people drive??????
> Theyre in there spliting and counting up the money the second the party is
> over!!!  But i do believe that our community of ravers as a people, are about
> love and a sense of community and all that good stuff....and yes i believe
> that there are still some good people out there who actually throw parties
> for the "community" and love and fun of it!!
> 
> About "techno" music becoming popular and extending to people who don't know
> what raves are about.....IT HAS ALREADY HAPPENED!!!!!!  Take a look around at
> the next party you go to....raves are TRENDY!!!  They havent much gotten to
> the underground parties, but they will!!!
> 
> hope i didnt offend anyone, sorry if i did
> 
> peace and love
> 
> jen

Dear Jen,

	You haven't offended me, but I do wish you would attach some 
names to the above.  This would allow the rest of us to make more 
informed judgements about the truth of what you say, and perhaps give 
those mentioned a chance to tell their side of it, if they are available 
to do so.  Who are these greedy promoters?  If they're so bad, why do you 
hang out with them?  What kind of cars *do* they drive?  If what you say 
is true, I want to know so I can avoid their parties.
	A while back I posted on the importance of the free flow of 
information.  This is not a criticism of you, but I think it would be 
helpful in general if people would share the important info that they 
have.  If know a particular DJ, promoter, or party is bad news, by all means 
tell us!  If the word doesn't get out, we can't hope to improve the 
quality of our scene by discouraging the bad elements.
	In the same spirit Jen, I'd be curious which radio station you 
refer to above.  Surely there is no need to keep the station's identity, 
or that of your friend who works there or the music director hidden.  
Or is there?  If you feel there is, I'd like to hear that as well.

Peace, Luv & Grooviness,
				<<< Starchild >>>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Radio stuff (continued)
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960228151552.20827A-100000@elroy.ucdavis.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I couldn't help but notice that someone mentioned programming radio shows 
based on what charts in the CMJ magazine.  Well, where does CMJ get those 
charts from?  I'll tell you!  It's from stations that submit their 
playlists on a wide variety of formats (country, Triple AAA, Adult 
Alternative, etc.) and then CMJ builds lists based on how many spins 
various tunes are getting.  It's not like some sort of MTV market 
survey.  Also, in case you haven't read CMJ (which I assume amny of you 
haven't since it's pretty much an industry rag) there is a section and 
chat called RMP that covers techno and industrial, but mostly techno.  
Now, let me give you a taste of what's charting on the CMJ RPM list:
top 10 as of 2/12/96
1) u-Ziq	In Pine Effect			Astralwerks
2) Various	Trip Hop Test Part Two		Moonshine
3) Various	Psychotrance3			Moonshine
4) Hardfloor	Da Damn Phreak Noize Phunk?	Harthouse-Eye Q
5) Frontline Assembly	Hard Wired		Metropolis
6) Various	Excursions in Ambience The 4th..Astralwerks
7) DJ Food	A Recipe for Disaster		Ninja Tune-Shadow
8) Chem. Bros.	Exit Planet Dust		Astralwerks
9) Leftfield	Leftism				Columbia-CRG
10) Keoki	Caterpiller (5")		Moonshine

also on this list is stuff from Astral Pilot, Loop Guru, Cygnus X, Goldie 
and Prototype 909 to name a few.  Now if a program director programmed a 
show from CMJ I think it would pretty much kick ass.  And I kjnow for a 
fact that once a record gets onto CMJ's top 25 RPM list, the distributors 
have _no_ problem sending out free copies, especially if your station 
reports to CMJ (which KDVS does! Yay!)
Anyway, just thought I would put in a couple more pennies...

--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+----+--+---

                 "Uncle" Noah Apodaca - napodaca@ucdavis.edu
                    Student, Disc Jockey, Resident Advisor

here's a thought:
I know that profit motives can be ugly things, and sometimes it may
seem like the rave scene or the radio stations are becoming repulsively
commercialized, but there's a fundamental scientific law which I think
proves that the real vibe (pick your own definitions of real here)
won't ever go away: nature abhors a vacuum, and so as long as there is
desire for a better way, the better way will come.  If there's a vacuum,
a noticeable and palpable lack of the real vibe, those of us who want that
real vibe to exist will rush and fill that vacuum, and we will do it as 
quickly and as easily as possible, moving in the same way that water rushes
down the side of a hill: it takes the path of least resistance, and as 
water slides around rocks and branches that are in its way, ravers tiptoe
past unsympathetic police officers and duck under curfew restrictions,
on their way to finding the real vibe.  Any thoughts on this one?

Timothy

_____________________________________________
sidewalk@uclink2
UC Berkeley
"No no no, I don't smoke because I'm addicted, silly!
 Cigarettes are just one of my props"
				     -- a street kid in Berkeley

> 
> 
> here's a thought:
> I know that profit motives can be ugly things, and sometimes it may
> seem like the rave scene or the radio stations are becoming repulsively
> commercialized, but there's a fundamental scientific law which I think
> proves that the real vibe (pick your own definitions of real here)
> won't ever go away: nature abhors a vacuum, and so as long as there is
> desire for a better way, the better way will come.  If there's a vacuum,
> a noticeable and palpable lack of the real vibe, those of us who want that
> real vibe to exist will rush and fill that vacuum, and we will do it as 
> quickly and as easily as possible, moving in the same way that water rushes
> down the side of a hill: it takes the path of least resistance, and as 
> water slides around rocks and branches that are in its way, ravers tiptoe
> past unsympathetic police officers and duck under curfew restrictions,
> on their way to finding the real vibe.  Any thoughts on this one?

Hmmm, (rubbing my chin in philosophical contemplation), I like to 
believe that there is an actual force pulling us into this vibe
you are talking about.  Your theory seems to say that good and
bad vibe will equal out.  So, if we were all ravers on this planet, 
there would be a bad vibe vacuum.  So, does this mean that a 
small subculture would duck the PLUR and have their own gatherings
and mailing lists where they talk about how all this PLUR stuff is
just not for them... that the universe is an evil, competive place,
where you can't get ahead by being nice, but instead by clawing your
way to the top of the heap?

Back to my mysterious force theory, what is it?  Maybe eons ago
aliens tampered with some people's genetic blueprint... a change that
would not manifest until triggered by an signal that indicating that
the planet had reached a certian level of technical knowlege.  This
signal, generated by technology, would get into these altered genes
and trigger a gradual, yet definate, change of mental outlook by those
affected.  Those affected would "see the light" ei, gain incredible
knowledge about the universe (as programmed by aliens so many eons earlier), 
and take it upon themselves to start building a better world based on
the newly-manifested knowledge.  Once enough people were "affected"
with this knowledge, the aliens would return to Earth and welcome
us humans (now a wonderful, happy, spiritual race that worked together) into 
the galactic community.

-troy

Subject: Re: Money = Bad?and Radio stationsand formats
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Sure we all need to eat, we all need to get by!  I don't have a problem
with people making money off what they like to do.  I have a problem when
money and the lust for it influences powerfull social/artistic/musical
trends thru  mass marketing which is what commercial radio(TV also) is all
about (after all,the true aim of marketing is to simply creats artificial
wants and needs.. )  Anyway whenever anything gets "big" and has mass
appeal it loses all quality, take fast food for example, Taco Bell vs. any 
independently owned Mexican resturant ,Mc Donalds, I mean is that place
really quality? no, it's mass produced for mass profits.  So can I compare
fast food and record labels? maybee, is Moonshine and United DJ's of
America really putting out the best and most original tracks? IMHO, NO.  I
guess the problems I'm talking about are deeply rooted in our capitalist
system and part of what makes the underground music scene so beautifull is
that to some extent it's not part of that system.  For-example, Carl Craig,
one of the most respected  techno artist around was at a little resturant
playing for a few(relative to a rock concert) people, I mean that's
community, no glamour, glitz, bodyguards, ect.
Anyway- big time mass marketed profit driven ________(fill in the
blank)=poor quality

P.S. Another subject:  When large companies(labels, promoters,radio
stations) are involved any values,ideas,politics ect. that are part of the
musical scene to be exploited  will always be ignored; they're just not
profitible and if they are ever emphasized by the company, well it will be
to make money off of it.(Levis web site)

Have Fun,
Mark

>"RADIO PLAY" and subsequent responses got me thinkin'....
>
>In 1990 I left a regular DJ gig at Denver's Rock Island and moved back to S.F. 
>where I was hired by BGP to be Bill Graham's personal producer for small
>events 
>(mostly personal parties and fund-raisers at his residence).  Since Bill was 
>friends with many of "The Dead" it was not uncommon to mingle with the likes
>of 
>Jerry Garcia or Bob Weir.  As I'm not a Deadhead in any way, shape, or form I 
>always found it a strange juxtaposition to go to a Dead show and listen to
>loving 
>Deadheads in the parking lot talk about "f****n' capitalists" or the yuppies
>who 
>were at that point "invading their scene for profit."  Then a week later I'd
>be 
>at Bill Graham's mansion in the hills of Marin watching members of the Dead 
>cruise up the driveway in Porsches and BMWs.
>
>My point is this. To make the assumption that Bill Graham (promoter) or Jerry 
>Garcia (player) were not in it for the love of the music or the community 
>(Deadheads) would be wrong. They were lucky enough to make the passion of
>their 
>life their business and to fill other people with happiness in the process.
>Pick 
>an industry and the argument holds, Bill Gates (computers), Ken Grifffey Jr. 
>(baseball), etc.
>
>Making money at something isn't always bad.  Heck, in our market driven
>society 
>money pays the rent people.  Think of all the great DJs and Promoters that
>we've 
>lost over the years because they had to move on to something that does pay the 
>rent and does have the future to pay for a child's food and education.  But I 
>guess that they didn't really love the music as much.  Yeah right.
>
>Are Deadheads and Ravers related? 
>  
>Just a thought...
>Sunny   
>
>

On Wed, 28 Feb 1996, Jonathan Santos wrote:

> 'Dave Bayer' wrote:
> >         Is the "community" that has come out of rave based on the music or the
> > people within the community? 
> 
> That depends on where you are from.  The community that I am from is based on music.

	I find it hard to believe that you have a community without 
people. I don't care how the community formed, my point was that the 
community is based or is made up of certain type of people and I think 
this is obvious from the paragraph before:

[begin my quote]
      Underground parties have always been around and they always will
be. I have been to some really good parties in the UK yet techno is nearly
as mainstream as blur. There was a term for the dodgy folks who were into
techno but looked the look and sported the hard attitude cuz they were
everywhere. And you look around here, its a community to a certain degree
but we don't have the likes of what the travellers in Europe do or the
roaming party that goes up and down the coast of India is rumored to have.
[end my quote]

	Now before you jump on me for saying a "certain type of people", 
look around at what a community is what what common features exist within 
a community because, in my terms, this is what makes a community. You go 
to India and you follow 5000 people up and down the coast who you didn't 
know a month before, you have to have one of a couple mindsets - either 
really fucking independent, or able to interact with people on a certain 
level and offer up certain parts of yourself, or a combination. Otherwise 
you are gonna be one lonely person in a big group and most likely die 
from exposure cuz the storms are gonna pelt on you and you can only abuse 
people so much before they are gonna say, fine, fuck off. What I see as 
community is that group interaction which keeps everyone alive and safe 
to a certain degree.

dave

Christopher Solle wrote:

Are Deadheads and Ravers related?

I'll try to keep this short.  I started going to Dead shows when I was 15 (in
1985 eek!).  I did the whole Dead tour-road-trip thing all through high school
(in Wisconsin) and most of the way through college.  Needless to say, I was
seriously hooked on that whole scene.  Then, while I was in college (UCSC . . .
hi slugs!), a friend  took me to a Funky Tekno Tribe.  I HAVE NEVER HAD SO MUCH
FUN IN MY LIFE!  Funky Tekno had sense of unity and smiles that I loved (and
missed) from my early years as a kid on Dead tour PLUS some REALLY fabulous
music.  I had so much fun dancing and running around stamping everyone; to this
day I'm sure that I stamped EVERYONE at that party.  I felt like I had finally
found a really interesting, diverse group of people to groove with!  I think
that there is a whole lot of "cross-over" between the groups affectionately
called "Deadheads" and "Ravers".  (I've met neat ravers at Dead shows and neat
Deadheads at raves.)

"Sometimes you get shown the light, in the strangest of places, if you look at
it right"

warmly,


-- 
Anne Petrie                                                   
Third Wave Solutions, Inc.            
E-mail: anne@source.net
Remember, if you breathe and persist anything is possible.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 19:29:25 1996

From: Jamie Pauline Smith <spunk@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Re: Radio stations and formats
To: John Draper <crunch@well.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199602272345.PAA21242@mh1.well.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9602281923.A4603-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I am currently interning on a radio station, kscs, on Erik Spire's show 
the Electric Sound Sanctuary.  The decent thing about kzcs is that it is 
public, and not for profit.  However, they are community oriented and 
have p.c. issues to contend to .  I don't know how supportive of a 
station that played all underground sounds I would be because it would 
then become more mainstream than ever, and allow others to profit from 
it.  I think the airplay of our music should be kept low key.  It is nice 
to be able to tune in to a particular show, but to hear it 24/7 would 
take a way some to the pleasure of hearing it live.  Songs get played out 
fast enough as it is at raves alone, let alone the possibility of hearing 
"sweet dreams" (hee hee)  more than deserves makes me ill. Maybe I am too 
nastalgic for the truly underground.  Is this unprogressive?  Well, maybe 
so, but I'd rather pop in the tape of any dj than even deal with 
commercial radio.
my .02...
Jamie 

On Tue, 27 Feb 1996, John Draper wrote:

> They all SUCK BIG TIME,  here in the Bay Area.   How can be reverse this
> dispicable distinction of being one of very few radio station markets that
> DON'T have a 24 hour/7 days Techno,  House,  AMbient,  Acid Jazz format?
> 
> Large commercial radio stations only fucus on "Established" formats that
> sell products,  but Live 105 has (or had) the Masters Mix every evening at
> 9 pm,  but when I tune in,   I sure don't get techno.   I guess it's not
> on every day.   Of course KZSU has these House Marathons every so often,
> but their signal coverage is small.
> 
> Is there any way that we,  as a group of people,  who are interested in
> hearing (and supporting) techno on the radio.    Free Radio is ONE solution,
> but won't be effective in ALL areas,  and then,  there is the FCC to contend
> with.
> 
> Other solutions,   might be to approach commercial radio stations and talk to
> their station managers and program directors to see if they could try the
> format out for a set period of time.   Remember,  All radio stations want
> to do,  is to sell Commercial time,  IE:  to make money.
> 
> I propose the following,  and would like to volunteer my knowledge of radio
> station anatomy to the SFRave community in the hopes that it might actually
> result in hearing a good DJ do a weekly show for 3 hour sets or even one
> every day.
> 
> First step is to convence the station mananger that Techno/House music
> is popular.   A good approach would be to make an appointment with the
> dude,  perhaps over lunch,  down in the Haight.   Take him (the station
> manager) into Ameba,  Frequency-8,  and other rave related stores,  and
> ask him to count how many vehicles are blaring out Techno and House toons.
> 
> Perhaps Ameba or Frequency-8,   or a host of other rave proprieters would
> be willing to pay for commercial time to "Sponsor" such a program.   Radio
> station money mongers eat this shit up BIG TIME!!.
> 
> You just have to convince the station manager that Rave music SELLS COMMERCIALS
> and I'm certain that Martin O Brian,  Wicked,  and other promoters would
> like to have their events promoted on these shows.
> 
> I used to work in radio in another lifetime,  from programming to engineering,
> and am familiar with the anatomy of such.   I also used to be a DJ on KKUP
> Cupertino,  back in 1970.
> 
> As to which radio station to approach,  I would try for stations that already
> play techno like Live 105,   or the hip hop station at the top of the dial,
> whatever that is...
> 
> Lets see what we can do...
> 
> Crunchman
> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Feb 28 19:37:59 1996

In reply to something Christopher Solle wrote, Anne Petrie said:
> 
> Are Deadheads and Ravers related?
> 
> I'll try to keep this short.  I started going to Dead shows when I was 15 (in
> 1985 eek!).  I did the whole Dead tour-road-trip thing all through high 
> school (in Wisconsin) and most of the way through colleg

 I was never a "tourhead" , but I went to at least one Dead show a year.

> .....a friend  took me to a Funky Tekno Tribe.  I HAVE NEVER HAD SO MUCH
> FUN IN MY LIFE!  Funky Tekno had sense of unity and smiles that I loved (and
> missed) from my early years as a kid on Dead tour PLUS some REALLY fabulous
> music. 

 Ditto!

> ....  I think
> that there is a whole lot of "cross-over" between the groups affectionately
> called "Deadheads" and "Ravers".  (I've met neat ravers at Dead shows and 
> neat Deadheads at raves.)

 Yes - but ... it's too bad that musical tastes and prejudices probably keep
the groups apart more than getting them together.

 As for less than positive encounters , I've had 'em in both scenes. Mostly
rip-off artists attracted to large crowds , or folks who've taken too
many hits of who-knows-what . Still , I'd rather be at a rave or a Dead show
than , say , a death-metal rock concert triple header..
 
> "Sometimes you get shown the light, in the strangest of places, if you 
> look at it right"


 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA04815; Wed, 28 Feb 1996 21:06:38 -0800

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Radio stations and formats
Date: Wed, 28 Feb 96 21:05:21 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Fuck commercial radio. I don't want to listen to their annoying
advertisements or listen to their heavy rotation "modern rock" crap
shoved down the program manager's throat's via payola bribe scams set
up by the record companies. Play a song often enough and the crowd will
love it! They snach up those lame hit records at Tower to stop that
horrible Pavlovian drooling caused by some lame "hook" that they can't
get out of their head. (Sounds echo in their hollow heads, I guess!)

I don't need to be spoon fed techno in the same way. If the DJ's can
select their own material then that's great -- but that will never ever
ever happen at a commercial radio station. You gotta play those songs
off the "A list" over and over again or you get fired.

Because of that -- I try to listen to college, nonprofit, or public
radio exclusively. I don't care if nobody else does -- they can have
their "The Cure" or "Toto" or "Hootie and the Blowfish" or whatever.
It's all lame to me, and by properties of transitivity, people that
listen to this shit are pretty lame as well.

My favorite stations:
	KFJC (south bay, though I get it in SF) -- 89.7 FM
	KZSU (south bay) -- 90.1 FM
	KPFA (berkeley, fresno, etc) -- 94.1 FM

KFJC on Saturday Night 10PM-2AM has Ronnie Libido's "saturday night 
spinout" and he often plays excellent stuff -- techno, ambient, trip
hop non-lame industrial. ANother good KFJC DJ is "Mr. Goodwrench" who
also plays excellent ambient/techno/dub etc. On Sunday afternoon, KFJC
has some really good reggae/dub. And at 7PM-10PM on Sunday evening --
great conspiracy theory talk radio...

KPFA has some excellent shows as well in the evening (lots of talk
shows in the day with interesting left-oriented subjects). For example,
the other day, they had some excellent Latino "low riding" rap and or
drum/bass music. Doug Wendt has a great reggae show. Other times I've
heard good african "pop" shows, funk, etc. It all moves the booty with
niceness!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Are Deadheads and Ravers alike? I went to my first Rave in Madison in 92
when I was 14 (it helps having older brothers).Then I hit my first Dead
show Spring of 93 in Chicago at the Rosemont Horizon. I ended up not coming
home for 6 months or so. The GD vibe then was very beautiful and loving.
We raged every city, especially on the west coast. Almost every hotel in a
five mile radius of the coliseum would be packed with Deadheads expanding
their minds, listening to music etc. I continued to follow the Dead off and
on for the next three years<in fact it's what brought me to San Franpsycho>
I was also hitting raves<Tx,Ill,NC,Ga,Or,> To get to the point....things
fell apart for the Dead scene, DEA<OPERATION DEADEND> were every where.
There was even a special task force at the Atlanta shows for people who
liked to explore there minds like myself called REDDOG's<run every drug
dealer out of Georgia!!Scarrry...I also noticed that allot of people
started shooting heroin etc. I pray that the same doesn't happen to the
Rave scene. I've actually noticed the vibe is getting better<I left to live
in Dallas and since I've been back the vibe has been much more loving
etc>We all need to stay positive and love one another...dance in
celebration of life in the tradition of the archaic way of life to the beat
of the music...and if your going to use drugs, use them as a catalyst to
your higher self.

Forrest

Uncle Noah <napodaca@ucdavis.edu>
>I couldn't help but notice that someone mentioned programming radio shows 
>based on what charts in the CMJ magazine.  Well, where does CMJ get those 
>charts from?  I'll tell you!  It's from stations that submit their 
>playlists on a wide variety of formats (country, Triple AAA, Adult 
>Alternative, etc.) and then CMJ builds lists based on how many spins 
>various tunes are getting.  It's not like some sort of MTV market 
>survey.  Also, in case you haven't read CMJ ...

Doesn't the "C" in CMJ stand for "College" (College Music Journal,
right?) -- so by definition, good college stations will be figuring out
all the hip cool tunes for da youngins based on some of those
playlists. I know they do, and I think that's great.

Unfortunately, the "C" in CMJ doesn't carry over to the Commercial
radio world. Any Commercial radio DJ needn't bother wasting their time
reading up on the latest sounds because they have to play the crap the
program director told them to play or get fired. (And if the program
direkkktor doesn't tow the line, the rekkkid companies will stop
sending said program director that endless stream of cocaine and high
priced call girls that keeps them stupid, happy, and under the whip of
their masters). This, oh ecstacy-addled-ones, is how things actually
work in "the industry".

If anybody knows of a commercial radio station that plays stuff outta
CMJ, I'd like to hear about it. Cuz you know that Live 105, KMEL, and
all those other dunderhead stations plays stuff off off the DMJ
playlist  (dickhead music journal) which is some rag that circulates
among Sony/CBS/NBC/Warner/Westinghouse management ... eventually
resulting in David Letterman being forced to showcase lame "new" acts
like Pete Droge, Tadpole II Frog, or giving us fabulously vapid
soundtracks like that from "Waiting to Impale", "Spew-less", or
whatever.

------- Forwarded Message

FAIR Report:
PATRICK BUCHANAN -- IN HIS OWN WORDS
February 26, 1996                           Contact: Steven Rendall

In the flap over Larry Pratt and other unsavory characters
associated with the Patrick Buchanan campaign, journalists
typically framed the question: Is Buchanan linked to extremists and
bigots?  But there is a more basic question journalists should ask:
Is Patrick Buchanan himself an extremist and bigot?

Here is a sampling of Buchanan's views:

ON AFRICAN-AMERICANS

After Sen. Carol Moseley Braun blocked a federal patent for a
Confederate flag insignia, Buchanan wrote that she was "putting on
an act" by associating the Confederacy with slavery: "The War
Between the States was about independence, about self-
determination, about the right of a people to break free of a
government to which they could no longer give allegiance," Buchanan
asserted.  "How long is this endless groveling before every cry of
'racism' going to continue before the whole country collectively
throws up?" (syndicated column, 7/28/93)

On race relations in the late 1940s and early 1950s: "There were no
politics to polarize us then, to magnify every slight. The
'negroes' of Washington had their public schools, restaurants,
bars, movie houses, playgrounds and churches; and we had ours."
(Right from the Beginning, Buchanan's 1988 autobiography, p. 131)

Buchanan, who opposed virtually every civil rights law and court
decision of the last 30 years, published FBI smears of Martin
Luther King Jr. as his own editorials in the St. Louis Globe
Democrat in the mid-1960s. "We were among Hoover's conduits to the
American people," he boasted (Right from the Beginning, p. 283).

White House advisor Buchanan urged President Nixon in an April 1969
memo not to visit "the Widow King" on the first anniversary of
Martin Luther King's assassination, warning that a visit would
"outrage many, many people who believe Dr. King was a fraud and a
demagogue and perhaps worse.... Others consider him the Devil
incarnate. Dr. King is one of the most divisive men in contemporary
history." (New York Daily News, 10/1/90)

In a memo to President Nixon, Buchanan suggested that "integration
of blacks and whites -- but even more so, poor and well-to-do -- is
less likely to result in accommodation than it is in perpetual
friction, as the incapable are placed consciously by government
side by side with the capable." (Washington Post, 1/5/92)

In another memo from Buchanan to Nixon: "There is a legitimate
grievance in my view of white working-class people that every time,
on every issue, that the black militants loud-mouth it, we come up
with more money.... If we can give 50 Phantoms [jet fighters] to
the Jews, and a multi-billion dollar welfare program for the
blacks...why not help the Catholics save their collapsing school
system." (Boston Globe, 1/4/92)

Buchanan has repeatedly insisted that President Reagan did so much
for African-Americans that civil rights groups have no reason to
exist: "George Bush should have told the [NAACP convention] that
black America has grown up; that the NAACP should close up shop,
that its members should go home and reflect on JFK's admonition:
'Ask not what your country can do for you, but rather ask what you
can do for your country.'" (syndicated column, 7/26/88)

In a column sympathetic to ex-Klansman David Duke, Buchanan chided
the Republican Party for overreacting to Duke and his Nazi
"costume": "Take a hard look at Duke's portfolio of winning issues
and expropriate those not in conflict with GOP principles, [such
as] reverse discrimination against white folks." (syndicated
column, 2/25/89)

Trying to justify apartheid in South Africa, he denounced the
notion that "white rule of a black majority is inherently wrong.
Where did we get that idea?  The Founding Fathers did not believe
this." (syndicated column, 2/7/90) He referred admiringly to the
apartheid regime as the "Boer Republic": "Why are Americans
collaborating in a U.N. conspiracy to ruin her with sanctions?"
(syndicated column, 9/17/89)

ON IMMIGRANTS AND PEOPLE OF COLOR:

"There is nothing wrong with us sitting down and arguing that issue
that we are a European country." (Newsday, 11/15/92)

Buchanan on affirmative action: "How, then, can the feds justify
favoring sons of Hispanics over sons of white Americans who fought
in World War II or Vietnam?" (syndicated column, 1/23/95)

In a September 1993 speech to the Christian Coalition, Buchanan
described multiculturalism as "an across-the-board assault on our
Anglo-American heritage."

"If we had to take a million immigrants in, say Zulus, next year,
or Englishmen, and put them up in Virginia, what group would be
easier to assimilate and would cause less problems for the people
of Virginia?" ("This Week With David Brinkley," 1/8/91)

ON JEWS:

Buchanan referred to Capitol Hill as "Israeli-occupied territory."
(St. Louis Post Dispatch, 10/20/90)

During the Gulf crisis: "There are only two groups that are beating
the drums for war in the Middle East -- the Israeli defense
ministry and its 'amen corner' in the United States." ("McLaughlin
Group," 8/26/90)

In a 1977 column, Buchanan said that despite Hitler's anti-Semitic
and genocidal tendencies, he was "an individual of great
courage...Hitler's success was not based on his extraordinary gifts
alone. His genius was an intuitive sense of the mushiness, the
character flaws, the weakness masquerading as morality that was in
the hearts of the statesmen who stood in his path." (The Guardian,
1/14/92)

Writing of "group fantasies of martyrdom," Buchanan challenged the
historical record that thousands of Jews were gassed to death by
diesel exhaust at Treblinka: "Diesel engines do not emit enough
carbon monoxide to kill anybody." (New Republic, 10/22/90)
Buchanan's columns have run in the Liberty Lobby's Spotlight, the
German-American National PAC newsletter and other publications that
claim Nazi death camps are a Zionist concoction.

Buchanan called for closing the U.S. Justice Department's Office of
Special Investigations, which prosecuted Nazi war criminals,
because it was "running down 70-year-old camp guards." (New York
Times, 4/21/87)

Buchanan was vehement in pushing President Reagan -- despite
protests -- to visit Germany's Bitburg cemetery, where Nazi SS
troops were buried.  At a White House meeting, Buchanan reportedly
reminded Jewish leaders that they were "Americans first" -- and
repeatedly scrawled the phrase "Succumbing to the pressure of the
Jews" in his notebook.  Buchanan was credited with crafting Ronald
Reagan's line that the SS troops buried at Bitburg were "victims
just as surely as the victims in the concentration camps." (New
York Times, 5/16/85; New Republic, 1/22/96)

After Cardinal O'Connor criticized anti-Semitism during the
controversy over construction of a convent near Auschwitz, Buchanan
wrote: "If U.S. Jewry takes the clucking appeasement of the
Catholic cardinalate as indicative of our submission, it is
mistaken. When Cardinal O'Connor of New York seeks to soothe the
always irate Elie Wiesel by reassuring him 'there are many
Catholics who are anti-Semitic'...he speaks for himself. Be not
afraid, Your Eminence; just step aside, there are bishops and
priests ready to assume the role of defender of the faith." (New
Republic, 10/22/90)

The Buchanan '96 campaign's World Wide Web site included an article
blaming the death of White House aide Vincent Foster on the Israeli
intelligence agency, Mossad -- and alleging that Foster and Hillary
Clinton were Mossad spies. (The campaign removed the article after
its existence was reported by a Jewish on-line news service; Jewish
Telegraphic Agency, 2/21/96.)

In his September 1993 speech to the Christian Coalition, Buchanan
declared: "Our culture is superior.  Our culture is superior
because our religion is Christianity and that is the truth that
makes men free." (ADL Report, 1994)

ON GAYS:

In a 1972 memo to Richard Nixon, Buchanan referred to one of George
McGovern's leading financial contributors as a "screaming fairy."
(Newsday, 2/8/89)  Buchanan has repeatedly used the term
"sodomites," and has referred to gays as "the pederast
proletariat." (Washington Post, 2/9/92)

"Homosexuality involves sexual acts most men consider not only
immoral, but filthy.  The reason public men rarely say aloud what
most say privately is they are fearful of being branded 'bigots' by
an intolerant liberal orthodoxy that holds, against all evidence
and experience, that homosexuality is a normal, healthy lifestyle."
(syndicated column, 9/3/89)

In a 1977 column urging a "thrashing" of gay groups, Buchanan
wrote: "Homosexuality is not a civil right.  Its rise almost always
is accompanied, as in the Weimar Republic, with a decay of society
and a collapse of its basic cinder block, the family." (New
Republic, 3/30/92)

"Gay rights activists seek to substitute, for laws rooted in Judeo-
Christian morality, laws rooted in the secular humanist belief that
all consensual sexual acts are morally equal.  That belief is anti-
biblical and amoral; to codify it into law is to codify a lie."
(Buchanan column in Wall Street Journal, 1/21/93)

On AIDS, Buchanan wrote in 1983: "The poor homosexuals -- they have
declared war upon nature, and now nature is extracting an awful
retribution (AIDS)." (Los Angeles Times, 11/28/86)  Later that
year, he demanded that New York City Ed Koch and New York Gov.
Mario Cuomo cancel the Gay Pride Parade or else "be held personally
responsible for the spread of the AIDS plague."  "With 80,000 dead
of AIDS, our promiscuous homosexuals appear literally hell-bent on
Satanism and suicide," Buchanan wrote in 1990 (syndicated column,
10/17/90).  In the 1992 campaign, he declared: "AIDS is nature's
retribution for violating the laws of nature." (Seattle Times,
7/31/93)

ON WOMEN:

"Rail as they will about 'discrimination,' women are simply not
endowed by nature with the same measures of single-minded ambition
and the will to succeed in the fiercely competitive world of
Western capitalism." (syndicated column, 11/22/83)

"The real liberators of American women were not the feminist
noise-makers, they were the automobile, the supermarket, the
shopping center, the dishwasher, the washer-dryer, the
freezer." (Right from the Beginning, p. 149)

"If a woman has come to believe that divorce is the answer to
every difficult marriage, that career comes before children
... no democratic government can impose another set of values
upon her." (Right from the Beginning, p. 341)

ON DEMOCRACY:

Attacking what he considers the "democratist temptation, the
worship of democracy as a form of governance," Buchanan commented:
"Like all idolatries, democratism substitutes a false god for the
real, a love of process for a love of country." (Patrick J.
Buchanan: From the Right, newsletter, Spring/90)

In a January, 1991 column, Buchanan suggested that "quasi-
dictatorial rule" might be the solution to the problems of big
municipalities and the federal fiscal crisis: "If the people are
corrupt, the more democracy, the worse the government." (Washington
Times, 1/9/91)  He has written disparagingly of the "one man, one
vote Earl Warren system."

In Right from the Beginning, Buchanan refers to Spanish dictator
Francisco Franco as a "Catholic savior."  He called Franco, along
with Chile's Gen. Pinochet, "soldier-patriots."  (syndicated column
9/17/89) Both men overthrew democracy in their countries.

Buchanan devotes a chapter of his autobiography -- "As We Remember
Joe" -- to defending Senator Joe McCarthy. He advocated that Nixon
"burn the tapes" during Watergate, and he criticized Reagan for
failing to pardon Oliver North over Iran-contra.

Buchanan, shortly before he announced he was running for president
in 1995: "You just wait until 1996, then you'll see a real right-
wing tyrant." (The Nation, 6/26/95)

                                  ***

For information on FAIR, send a blank e-mail message to
fair-info@fair.org or visit out web site at:
http://www.fair.org/fair
You can subscribe to FAIR's magazine, EXTRA!, by calling our
subscription service at 800-847-3993.

On Wed, 28 Feb 1996, anne petrie wrote:

> Christopher Solle wrote:
> 
> Are Deadheads and Ravers related?
> 
> I'll try to keep this short.  I started going to Dead shows when I was 15 (in
> 1985 eek!).  

	meee tooo!!!  in 1985 i was 12...my first show in lewiston, 
maine.  i started listening to the dead that summer then they played down 
the street from my house...what an adventure that was! if you like the 
dead, check out my web page...it's really cute! ;)  i also was a guest 
singer with a NE based dead band called the "broken men" for a few 
years.  boy, was that a fun time.  but, i really like the dead/techno 
crossover...i think it's really neat.  like, before i startd listening to 
techno i read alot of terrance mckenna then was surprised to find of his 
involvement with space-time continuum...for me i just never knew this 
world existed and it was (and still is) very exciting for me!  so it's a 
good blend :)  

		        http://www.teleport.com/~shakti

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 29 09:55:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA17511; Thu, 29 Feb 1996 09:55:04 -0800

	id MAA14729; Thu, 29 Feb 1996 12:54:10 -0500
Date: 29 Feb 96 12:51:16 EST
From: Leslie Ayres <71165.755@compuserve.com>
To: "sfraves@hyperreal.com" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Deadheads & Ravers
Message-ID: <960229175115_71165.755_GHL146-1@CompuServe.COM>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In reply to ..... Are Deadheads and Ravers related?

Even though I'm of an age that I could have been one of the very early
Deadheads, I never really got into the Dead or the Deadhead culture ...  and
then later in life, I was irresistably pulled into the rave scene.. and last
summer I had a chance to reflect on the similarities and differences ...

I went to a Kundalini party up in Washington a few hours south of Seattle in a
place called Rainbow Valley, which is a beautiful green secluded valley where
lots of Deadheads live, there are old schoolbuses and vans parked around, and
they have a whole community there..  and they lease (I guess) it to ravers for
parties ...  really a beautiful environment.

Some of the resident Deadheads were set up as vendors for our events, food and
coffee/hot chocolate (how nice to have real food to eat, hot coffee in the
morning!) and t-shirts, candles and stuff -- but mostly they didn't mingle into
our group (with a couple of interesting exceptions) --

Then the sun came up, and the mist was rising off of the grass as we were tired
and mellow from dancing and partying all night ... and I look down the dirt road
and here comes a couple probably in their late 40s, dressed in tie-dye and
hippie garb, with their steaming cups of coffee in hand, and their two little
boys running behind them, walking toward the dance area, to sort of check us out
and share our music and vibe for a little while -- And when they got to the
dance area, they just stood to the side and watched us, maybe not being moved by
the music, maybe not feeling part of the group, maybe just being sleepy and not
yet started on their day...

And I realized that we were different and yet the same - sort of like looking at
yourself at another age, through a looking glass -- I felt a real connection
with them in a way, like a feeling of the past passing on to the future -- it
was especially strong for me, because I'm 42 and know that I have one foot in
each side --  

The moral of this story?  I have no idea, I just know I'll never forget that
moment.  Certainly not all Deadheads are old, and certainly not all ravers are
young -- but as a symbol of a generation, one seems to have passed to the next
--

so....     (did you make it this far in this rambling story?)  
peace and love however you can make it,

leslie   : )

Precedence: bulk

        I'm so glad this discussion has opened up the way it has!  Long
before it started, I came to the conclusion, based on six years of going to
Dead shows and one and a half years of raving, that the vibe of PLUR is the
same, it's just the music that's different.  And even though the style of
music differs, the concept of being joined and of celebrating life and love
through dance is the same.  It's incredible!  I feel that if people deny
this just because they don't want to be associated with one "lifestyle" or
the other, they are too uptight, and probably haven't come to fully
understand themselves and how they fit into this whole puzzle.  I hope more
fellow "Raving Deadheads" will share their thoughts on all this, because
the understanding will no doubt lead to a larger, more beautiful community.
We reach!

Dizzy with possibilities,

- E

This relates to the ongoing "radio stations and formats" discussion.  KSJS
(San Jose State University's station) has a program, M-F, 2am-6pm, called
"Daytime Pleasure."  According to the Web site (www.ksjs.org), it plays
industrial, techno, etherial [sp], hardcore, world, ambient, international,
and experimental music.  Might be worth checking out!  KSJS is 90.5FM.

Shameless plug :)

pushed you to realize that "the torch has been passed", ie. the sixties are

sweetness and light in humanity.

it is said by some that ravers are the hippies of the '90s .  Ina huge 
way that's true.  we rebel from the society as a whole and go underground 
to find love.

Plus, many of my raver friends , including myself love both the 
underground music and the music from groups like the g-dead and phish < i 
hope I didn't offend anyone by placing them together, but they ARE similar!>
When a show comes to town <or did - by jerry>  I would often recognize 
people from the rave scene!!

I agree that the two groups are VERY similar!! - good compliment - I'd say

This weekend starts early with several appealing Leap Day parties; 
then Detroit's Derrick May, Stacey Pullen and Juan Atkins roll into town.
Friday's just overloaded though, with big parties all around the greater
Bay Area - so everyone should have something to do.  Saturday, Chrysalis
ought to be good, and they promise it won't be at the Acme warehouse.



                                THE SFR CALENDAR

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Feb 29 14:14:52 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id OAA17116; Thu, 29 Feb 1996 14:14:52 -0800
Received: from lazlo.steam.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA17077; Thu, 29 Feb 1996 14:14:36 -0800
Received: from club.net (www.club.net [157.22.222.22]) by lazlo.steam.com (8.7.3/8.6.12) with ESMTP id NAA07931 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 29 Feb 1996 13:40:29 -0800 (PST)
Received: from [157.22.222.111] by club.net
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.1b9); Thu, 29 Feb 1996 13:34:53 -0800
Message-Id: <v02140b1cad5bc9872d5c@[157.22.222.111]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 29 Feb 1996 13:34:29 -0800
To: James.C.Lippmeier@Dartmouth.EDU (James C. Lippmeier),
        Captain.Havoc@Dartmouth.EDU (Captain Havoc)
From: "Wayne D. Correia" <wayne@club.net>
Subject: Re: White Power Music
Cc: BOSTON-RAVES@ccs.neu.edu, pb-cle-raves@hyperreal.com,
        mw-raves@hyperreal.com, ne-raves@world.std.com, mtnraves@xmission.com,
        v-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Let me say first that I am not a white power supporter by any means.

Now that we have that out of the way, I have to say that it is really
uncool and (ideally) un-american to try to stifle the creation of their
news group or their free speech, regardless of how offensive *you* find it.

And really, who cares if "rec.music.white-power" is approved? If you don't
like what's there, just don't subscribe! There are quite a few news groups
that are out there that I have no interest in, but I am not running around
trying to muster anti-{insert your least favorite news group here}-group
support.

What if there were a more "moral" organization that were opposed to the
rave scene that tried to muster support to crush us from having our
rave-related community online? There are quite a few people in the US that
are definitely anti-rave, and thank god that they have the decency to just
let us "live and let live." I don't want to have to spent all my energy to
defend our right to free speech and collaboration on the Internet. First
"rec.music.white-power" gets attacked, and then who's next? Hyperreal?
"alt.rave"? Get it?

Now let's not get into a "raving is OK vs. rec.music.white-power is not OK"
type argument. That's not the point. At all. The specifics of the topics
are not what my rebuttal is about. It's about free speech, plain and
simple. Nothing more, nothing less.

---

>Front, had to say about this vote, on February 21, on his
>RESISTANCE mailing list:
>
>   "There is a call for votes
>   coming on rec.music.white-power in the next week
>   or so, and you will be notified in a special issue of
>   RREN exactly what to do.  FOLLOW THE
>   INSTRUCTIONS TO THE LETTER.  Let me be
>   perfectly blunt and state that we have more than
>   enough "net-nazis" to win this thing hands-down.
>   But every one of you must vote YES!  And just
>   voting yes means nothing unless you do it properly.
>   So you have been forewarned.  The instructions
>   are coming to your email box soon, and they
>   are not complicated.  Just follow them as told,
>   and we will have a WP music newsgroup finally!"
>
>If Mr. Burdi's confidence disturbs you, please give this
>letter the _widest_ possible distribution, and help us deliver
>the largest NO vote in the history of UseNet.
>
>***
>
>If you agree with me, please register your vote. In order to
>do that, send a message to: music-vote@sub-rosa.com
>
>The content of the message should read:
>
>    I vote NO on rec.music.white-power
>
>and nothing else.
>
>Do _not_ vote twice - that would constitute voting fraud.
>
>*** If you want more info on this, go to "Bulletings -- Jewish Life" from the
>blitz mail screen. ***

>Leslie wrote:
>
>>And I realized that we were different and yet the same - sort of like looking
>>at yourself at another age, through a looking glass -- I felt a real
>connection
>>with them in a way, like a feeling of the past passing on to the future -- it
>>was especially strong for me, because I'm 42 and know that I have one foot in
>>each side --
>>The moral of this story?  I have no idea, I just know I'll never forget that
>>moment.  Certainly not all Deadheads are old, and certainly not all ravers are
>>young -- but as a symbol of a generation, one seems to have passed to the
>next"
>
>What a wonderful moment!  A moral of the story?  Well, perhaps, this moment
>pushed you to realize that "the torch has been passed", ie. the sixties are
>truly over, but we didn't learn all the stuff we were supposed to, so some of
>those same ideals have been passed on to us in an attempt to cultivate
>sweetness and light in humanity.
>
>I love these "significant-feeling-moments", they are great reality checks.
>
>warmly,
>
>--
>Anne Petrie
>Third Wave Solutions, Inc.
>E-mail: anne@source.net
>Remember, if you breathe and persist anything is possible.

To which I reply: I see it not so much as a torch passing, or a generation
giving way to a new one, but that the common thread of PLUR is eternal, and
is shared by many diverse subcultures.  It flows through us, age
notwithstanding.  "It surrounds us, penetrates us; it binds the galaxy
together."  (Shameless quote!)  So, let us perpetuate it, and, rather than
pass it on, share it, thus becoming an ever-growing family!

Hugz to all,

- E

begin forwarded registration information... (register now to save $$$)

From: STUMANGRUM@aol.com
To: burnman-list@well.com
Subject: BM 96 Registration Materials

Whats follows is another advance release from the Spring 96 "Building Burning
Man" newsletter. '96 Registration form included at end'o'file; get a $10
discount if you send it in before June 1st!

*************************************************

SURVIVAL

Visitors to the playa should not come as spectators to a show. Instead, they
will encounter an interactive experience; a spontaneous outpouring of energy
that is created by our community itself. Burning Man is a phenomenon which
springs from your immediate involvement. We are not funded by grants or
product endorsements. We depend upon direct contributions. Hundreds of people
are now engaged in creating this year's event. Here is how you can help:

CONTRIBUTE
Send in your registration fee today!  By purchasing your ticket now for $25
you can save $10. Beginning in June tickets to the event will cost $35. Buy a
t-shirt or a video. If you can, make an extra contribution (see the check box
on order form). Many new projects- Mudhenge, the Inferno, a new public
transit project, and an elaborated Man-are being readied for 1996. None of
this will happen without your early support. If you are among those people
who already know they are coming to Burning Man, help us now.

VOLUNTEER
There is only one way to become a member of the Project.  You must do
something. Burning Man is a society of activists. Later this year we will
solicit volunteers to help us run the infrastructure of our camp. We are now
recruiting experienced builders, people to do data entry and distribute
flyers, help with clerical tasks, and individuals who can assist with
transport of materials to Nevada throughout the year. If you have any skill
or resource which you think might help us in our preparations, please call
our Hotline.

ARTISTS
In addition to the "Inferno," Burning Man is planning many new art
initiatives in 1996.  Our burning pageant in the desert on Sunday, September
1, will feature large-scale portable effigies that can be raised overhead.
 Puppeteers, model makers, stilt walkers, fire performers, etc.-please
contact us.  We also need folks to assist us in casting a large number of
plaster brains (yes, brains ) that will be featured at our premier show on
March 23 at the Minna Street Gallery in San Francisco.

MUDHENGE
In 1995 our camp was inundated by a rainstorm and mudpeople sprang from the
playa (you know who you are). In 1996 we will construct a temple and public
shower in which to house these rites. We invite all persons of mud to
worship, wallow, and bathe between the legs of "Water Woman" (Showers are
restricted to initiates. You must first get down in the mud). If you would
like to help construct and tend the temple, or wish to organize and schedule
an event here (i.e. mud wrestling, a mud procession, etc.) please contact our
Hotline.

PUBLIC TRANSIT
The playa of the Black Rock Desert is a fundamentally safe environment.
 Apart from the very real, dire, and life-threatening hazard of becoming lost
[please read the Survival Guide that is mailed to all registered
participants] the playa is as flat and as forgiving as the mattress of a
playpen. The greatest hazard that we face is self-created. Nearly every one
of the few serious accidents and injuries that we have witnessed during
Burning Man has involved automobiles. This year we encourage everyone to
bring bicycles. They are perfectly adapted to the hard-packed surface of the
playa.  We plan also to organize a pool of specially marked bicycles for
public use. If you can help us with this effort please call our Hotline.

FILM FEST
We are now accepting entries for the 2nd Annual Burning Man Film and Video
Festival. The deadline for submissions is July 4th. Please contact Coffee
Achievers at 415.826-3277. Ask for Hernan.

SETTLEMENT
This year, the city of Black Rock will sport a newly renovated downtown area
and a number of exurban hubs, or "meta-theme camps." If you want to create
your own city within a city, call the Hotline.

*************************************************

1996 REGISTRATION/ORDER FORM

Burning Man Festival
Wednesday, August 28 through Monday, September 2, 1996

The annual celebration of BURNING MAN will take place over Labor Day weekend
in the Black Rock Desert of Northern Nevada. All attendees need to register
for the event, and must bring their own shelter, food and water.

This form can be used to register and/or order Burning Man merchandise. Feel
free to make copies. If you are purchasing tickets you will receive your
registration packet (including 1996 map, survival guide, and schedule of
events) approximately one month before the festival.

Tickets: Purchase advance tickets now for Burning Man, August 28 - September
2, 1996.  We will mail you a ticket, your survival guide, map, and a detailed
schedule of events approximately one month before the event. Order now and
save! After June 1st, the price goes up to $35 per person.

Burning Man Video: Only the finest photons, hand-selected and lovingly
preserved on durable magnetic tape for your viewing pleasure. Relive past
glories or see what you missed in this 48-minute documentary by WeirdTV's
Chuck Cirino. A substantial portion of the proceeds benefit Burning Man.
 $19.95

T-shirts: Buy a Burning Man t-shirt, lovingly crafted from 100% cloth for
cool desert comfort. Screen printed on black in sizes L and XL. Always
fashionable; makes a great gift! Proceeds benefit the Burning Man Project.
 $15.00


*************************************************

To the list...... there have been several posts in recent weeks about news 
articles that discussed MDMA, but no one seems to have actuallly read the 
articles or can find them.  So after a little DB search, the following are a few
articles, mostly from the British press, that appeared over the past couple of 
months.  This is what is out in the press, correct information or not, its what 
the masses read. just so you know. 
Enjoy. -jc
    




             Copyright 1996 Caledonian Newspapers Ltd.    
                              The Herald (Glasgow)

                               February 13, 1996


HEADLINE: Pathologists uncover agony of ecstasy

BYLINE: By Alan Macdermid;Medical Correspondent;

BODY:
    A GRIM toll of damage to the liver, brain, and heart has been uncovered by
post-mortem examinations of young men who had been taking ecstasy and similar
rave drugs.

    Necrosis - gangrene-like rotting - was found in the liver of all seven of
the men, aged from 20-25, who were examined by forensic pathologists at
Sheffield University.

    Five also had necrosis or other damage to the heart, and four had brain
damage of one sort or another - blood clotting, swelling, and cell death in one,
haemorrhage in two, and severe swelling and bleeding in the fourth, consistent
with water intoxication.  

    Internal bleeding was found in the lungs of two of the men. Damage due to
loss of blood supply was seen in the lungs of a third.

    Reporting the cases in the Journal of Clinical Pharmacology, Dr Chris Milroy
and his colleagues said traces of ecstasy (MDMA) or other amphetamine
derivatives - Eve (MDEA) or MDA - were found in six of the victims.

    The seventh, a 23-year-old dying from progressive jaundice and liver
failure, had admitted regular ecstasy use.

    Another of the seven had collapsed in a disco, having drunk 14 litres of
water in an attempt to quench the thirst and hyperthermia associated with the
combination of ecstasy and dancing.

    Two also collapsed at a rave or disco, two were found dead or dying in bed,
and one collapsed in the street.

    Hyperthermia was present in only two of the seven cases, and the
pathologists suggest that damage was being caused independently of the effects
of hyperthermia.

    They point out that one of the problems associated with taking ecstasy is
the wide variation in the content of the tablets, some of which may be toxic.
Nevertheless, none of the seven had traces of contaminants in their blood - only
the drugs.

    It is estimated that 500,000 people in the UK take ecstasy every week. The
incidence of death has been described by the drug's defenders as very 
lowcompared with legal drugs such as alcohol or tobacco.

    These examination results indicate that people who regularly take ecstasy
may be risking serious and irreversible damage to their brains, hearts, and
livers.

Copyright 1996 Newspaper Publishing PLC   
                                The Independent

                           February 13, 1996, Tuesday


HEADLINE: Ecstasy users 'risking heart and liver damage'

BYLINE: GLENDA COOPER

BODY:
    GLENDA COOPER

    Long-term users of the drug ecstasy risk rotting their livers and damaging
their hearts and brains, as well as the short-term risk of overheating,
according to a study published today.

    The findings of the team led by Dr Chris Milroy, of the Department of
Forensic Pathology at Sheffield University, emerged from post-mortem
examinations of seven young men who died after taking ecstasy (MDMA) and a
related drug known as Eve (MDEA).

    In Britain, more than 500,000 people are said to use the drug each week.
Many people, including users, are aware of the dangers of overheating caused by
the drug which has led to deaths in the past. But recently the death of Leah
Betts highlighted the lesser known risk of drinking too much water after taking
ecstasy.  

    Seven deaths examined in the Journal of Clinical Pathology were investigated
over the last three years. They were men aged between 20 and 25. Three collapsed
at a rave or a disco, two were found in bed, one collapsed in the street, and
one was admitted to hospital with severe jaundice.

    The results suggest that although overheating - hyperthermia - is one of the
symptoms that can lead to death after taking ecstasy, also known as E, Adam or
XTC, there may be toxic effects on the liver and other organs.

    The researchers found that all the men's livers showed "dramatic changes"
with dead tissue seen in all cases. Similar damage was found in the hearts of
five of the men and swelling, bleeding and damaged nerves were evident in the
brain in three instances.

    One victim had severe swelling of the brain tissue as a result of having
drunk 14 litres of water in an attempt to quench his thirst.

    Internal bleeding was found in the lungs of two of the men and damage
because of loss of blood supply was seen in the lungs of a third. The changes
present in these deaths were the same as those from heatstroke.  But only two of
the men had suffered a sharp rise in body temperature with readings of 39.5C and
44C.    The paper also warns: "Another problem for the recreational drug taker 
is
the quality of tablets they take. Examination of ecstasy tablets . . .  has
shown that the contents of the tablets may vary greatly . . . With such material
the possibility of toxic contaminants being present is evident."

    Dr Milroy concluded: "The short-term risks of ecstasy use are becoming
increasingly more apparent, and questions must be asked about the long-term
effects on the brain, liver and heart, considering the pathology in those who
die."
    In the UK, ecstasy is now categorised as a Class A drug - equivalent to
heroin and cocaine - with penalties of up to seven years' imprisonment for
possession and life for supplying it others.


                        Copyright 1996 Reuters, Limited
                      February 13, 1996, Tuesday, BC cycle

HEADLINE: "Ecstasy" damages internal organs, researchers say

DATELINE: LONDON

BODY:
   Long-term use of Ecstasy, Europe's second most popular "recreational" drug
after cannabis, can destroy the liver and damage the heart and brain, a study
released Tuesday found.

   The effects were clearly seen in young men in their early 20s, indicating
that the drug quickly causes widespread damage.

   Forensic pathologists at Sheffield University said autopsies of seven young
men who had died after taking Ecstasy found "striking changes" in all their
livers, including large areas of dead tissue. In one case there was "massive"
damage.  

   Their hearts were also damaged, as were the brains of three of them. Internal
bleeding was found in the lungs of two and damage from loss of blood supply in
the lungs of a third.

   Dr. Robert Forrest, who worked on the study, said all the men had levels of
Ecstasy in their blood, which indicated the drug caused the damage. Three of the
men, aged between 20 and 25, collapsed at a "rave" or dance party or at a disco.

   "There's nothing else to cause it," he said in a telephone interview. "You
find the drug levels there, you find the pathological changes and you are faced
with somebody dead, the question is, did the drug cause it?"
   Doctors say the drug has killed at least 60 people in Britain. The case of
Leah Betts, who died after taking one dose of the drug on her 18th birthday,
caused a nationwide outcry about its danger.
   A Council of Europe report last year showed it was the continent's most
popular recreational drug after cannabis.
   Forrest said further study was needed, but urged other doctors to make
careful autopsies of young people who died after taking drugs.
   "The short-term risks of Ecstasy use are becoming increasingly more apparent,
and questions must be asked about the long-term effects on the brain, liver and
heart, considering the pathology in those who die," the researchers wrote in the
Journal of Clinical Pathology.
   The report said the damage to their organs was consistent with overheating-
which does cause some Ecstasy deaths. Users dance for for hours, often either
suffering from dehydration, or drinking lethal amounts of water in an attempt to
avoid it.   But it was also consistent with amphetamine use. "You get exactly 
the same
thing in a cocaine overdose," Forrest said.
   Ecstasy, clinically known as methylenedioxymethylamphetamine, (MDMA), was
first developed as an appetite suppressant. A derivative of amphetamine, it is a
stimulant causing a rush of energy and heightened perception.

>by the way, what do people call you? S seems so ssssssssshort?

So you reeeeaaaaaalllyyyy want to know, huh?  Well... I'll tell you, but 
then I'll be forced to hug you...  I guess I never put out an introduction 
on the list, so here goes...

My name is Todd.  I'm 6'1", 190lbs., fairly athletic, brown short hair, 
short brown goatee, brown eyes.  I'm a Sr. Applications Engr. for DHL 
Airways, Inc., in Redwood City, which is a fancy way of saying I'm a 
programmer that knows what he's doing.  I'm completely serious at work, part 
good-natured, part tie and jacket wearing hard-ass.  Outside of work I'm the 
biggest, goofiest kid you'll ever meet, usually high energy and bouncy.  I 
currently live in Mountain View, been in Cal for 13 years.  I'm from 
Tallahassee FL originally, although I've been all over the place.  I'm a 
romantic, a Southern gentleman at heart and in practice, and the coolest 
uncle in the world, bar none, to my 3 year old nephew Joey and my 10 month 
old niece Katelyn.  I've got one foot solidly in the conservative, 
family-oriented, 9-5 world, and one foot dancing across the line to the 
loose, partying, care-free, liberal, PLUR practicing, chemically assisted 
world.  I'm a 31 year old good ole country boy gone to the big city.  I'm a 
macho guy that actually has a stuffed monkey toy in the back seat of his car 
named "Elvis" for when my nephew is in the car.  I'm a 
foaming-at-the-mouth-anti-racist, screaming-anti-pedophile, non-homophobe, 
open-minded, soft-spoken, butt-kicker-of-bullies, Democrat.  I'm the guy the 
ladies crowd close to when the weirdos are staring, and I'm the guy little 
kids gravitate to with big grins because I'm probably already playing with 
their toys anyway, so I must be alright.  I cook killer Chinese, Japanese, 
French, and Italian food, and now I'm learning Thai.  I include cheesed 
grits when I cook breakfast for guests.  I have a to-die-for-pumpkin pie 
recipe that I've included in the Southern recipe book I've started, "Uncle 
Todd's Cookbook".  I grow my own Thai peppers because nothing is ever hot 
enough, and I cook a homemade chili that will peel the tiles off the Space 
Shuttle.  I bike on a 10-speed I built, I lift weights, I play basketball, I 
love hiking.  I have a love of the ocean.  In fact I think that, if I'd been 
born 100 years ago, I'd have been a sailor just for the adventure.  I'm part 
Irish, English, Scottish, and 1/8 Greek.  I speak some Spanish and Japanese, 
a smidgen of French, and dribs and drabs of Cantonese, Malaysian, and 
Italian.  I'm not big on alcohol, but I drink Guiness when I'm in a pub, 
Tanqeria (sp?) and tonic at formal parties, Tequila when I'm out with the 
guys whuppin' their butts in pool.  I am loyal to a fault and would put 
myself between a bullet and anyone I called friend.  I liked Cuban cigars 
BEFORE it was fashionable.  I draw fairly well.  I have 10 hamsters -- about 
6 too many -- and a deep love of friendly cats and big sweet dogs, although 
my apartment complex doesn't allow them.  I like Rock, Soul, a little 
country -- no twang-de-twang, please -- and I'm rapidly building a 
collection of Techno and House.

I LOVE to dance.  And I DO have rhythm...  ;)

If you're really nice to me, I'll tell you what the SDream came from some time.

>(I agree on the Buchanan issue, he has the least chance to beat Clinton)

the guts to at least try some things that other politicians promise and rant 
and rave (?!) about but wouldn't actually touch with a 10-foot pole.  And 
he's human.  I mean, I actually like him!  When he was in Russia and Yeltsin 
was cracking him up, I started laughing with him!  That would have been me 
up there, giggling and clapping Yeltsin on the shoulder.  Did you see that?  
It makes you feel good about the direction the world is going, when the 
world leaders can joke and buddy around without the posturing and 
threatening, y'know?

It may not be GOOD, but Wild 107 DOES play quite a bit of house music.
Since it has become a trendy item, I have heard quite a lot of
303-like squealing on that station along with the usual slow jams and
hiphop.  This is where to look for the commercialization of the scene;
it's format is really quite similar to London's Kiss FM.

David

I too am older -- 41 -- and have been lurking here for a few weeks.

My original intention was just to maybe find out more about techno, 
which I really am just now discovering (thank you KALX) but I've
been sitting here fascinated by these messages. The scene seems
like a high-tech version of the scenes I was in 20 years ago: 
positive, community-oriented, loving... I thought such things were 
passe' as the Hippies became objects of ridicule.  Yeah, peace and 
love, what a stupid fucking idea...

It's also encouraging, because I've been kind of reticent to check
it out for fear of feeling out of place.  Hmm, maybe I'll check it 
out... so if y'all see an Old Fart looking a little bashful by the 
sidelines, give 'im a smile.

A USENET call for votes, is just that -- a call for votes. So I don't
see any problem with the "anti white power" faction ralling against 
the creation of the newsgroup, just like "pro white power" folks will
rally for the creation of the newsgroup. Let the arbitrators get their
numbers and decide. Either that, or you don't agree with the concepts
of democracy and voting. 

The tyranny of the populace can go against the fringe bad as it can go
against the fringe good. You have to accept that or assume some other
kind of system where super-geniuses-in-the-know do all the thinking for
a populace that is too dumb to think for themselves. I like democracy
better. It averages everything, both good and bad.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

BY YOUR COMMAND:

        First, what's going on tonight, Thursday 2/29/96.....oh my it's a
leap year.

        Second, looking for last weeks calendar and this weeks if it's out
yet, so could some kind soul please send it to me.

        Third, I've been down for over a week sleeping with my new system
which at this point is about 85% stable and going up(yes, I'm cohabiting for
all you tech heads in Win 95, with unsupported hardware, & without even a
warning). However, and to my dismay my ISP provider went  down as well, and
the unthinkable happened. They lost a weeks worth of mail, argh!!!!!! So if
you sent me something from Friday 2/23/96, until today, I haven't gotten it
& won't unless you resend.

        Fourth, I'm looking at my Alameda County Sample Ballot for the Green
party, and yes I see Ralph Nader is their parties Candidate for President of
the United States. WE have a chance to place a good honest person in office,
please don't pass this one by. If anyone would like to discuss this with me,
please e-mail me privately, thanks.

        Finally, with my new system I picked up Delrina's CommSuite for
WIN95, by Symantec. It's an integrated Web Browser, Fax Software,
Communications Packages with Full Internet Functionality(eg Mail, IRC, FTP,
Gopher ...etc), all in one package. It seems to work seamlessly, however the
Web Browsers appearance leaves something to be desired compared to Netscape,
which has wonderful appeal visually but lacks functionality. But for intro
price of $100 that I paid for  it at CompUSA it's worth it. You will pay at
least that to register all the other products that are out there and get
something less.

Sin
Brian Darkness

[ to sfraves list ]

 Something that occured to me , inspired by a recent , somewhat bitter post.

 I started going to raves at about 1993. Since then , I've met a lot of
SFRavers , and I'm glad to see them at the events I go to. It's an added
small pleasure every time I see a familiar face , and we recognize each other.

 However - I rarely see rave folks outside of raves. It hadn't occured to
me to wonder why in a serious manner until tonight.

 A couple of factors that might explain this -

 * I'm not a very social person to begin with. Before raves , my socialising
   was limited to girlfriends and just a few others. I'm not an extrovert or
   a "party person" . It takes awhile for me to get into "friendship" mode
   with any individual.
 * By the time I started going to raves , I had already built up a group of
   friends that I still socialise with. I suspect that I'm thinking in a
   subconscious sense that I have just enough friends that I can "handle" . 
   More would add a certain psychic stress .
 * I'm married to someone who likes rave music and likes to go to the 
    occasional event , but , due to health limitations , she can't go to a lot
    of the raves I go to. So , to compensate , I spent more "special time"
    with her instead of raving .
 *  I'm older than most ravers , and a bit of "generation gap" might be 
    preventing the establishing of more friendships with rave folks outside 
    of a rave environment.
 *  Folks don't want me as a friend outside of a rave environment. Of course,
    given the above , I may be giving off a "don't bug me" vibe of some sort...
 *  I live in Sunnyvale , which is about 40 miles south of San Francisco. 
    That prevents me from doing casual "lets go out to dinner now" kind of
    stuff with SF and East Bay ravers. 

 What do you folks think? I also want to say , that I hope I haven't hurt 
anyone's feelings by implying that you folks are "second-class" friends. 
And , this really isn't a call for a lot of sympathetic email giving be ASCII 
hugs 'n such. I'm just asking .... 

  Larry "doesn't play or interact well with others" Ching / larryc@netcom.com
